content:
Posted: July 23, 2015
 A real feat...	This is the game Simcity was trying to be. If you know and have played Simcity, then you know what I mean. It was a brilliant effort, that was somehow hindered, perhaps by EA's greed. This is the best parts of Simcity, but so much more. Everything is done... well, just about perfectly - and by a team that, compared to Maxis's workforce, is tiny. I'd do a list of pros and cons about now, but the list of pros for this game might be too long. Instead...The most brilliant things this have over Simcity: - MASSIVE cities. This one can't be avoided. You start in a square roughly the size of Simcity's. You can then buy another EIGHT. So, yeah, it's 9 times the size of Simcity. You can have even more (25!) with the help of a mod, which brings me on to my next point... - Mods. And Steam Workshop integration. I don't think I've played a game where adding mods was so easy and fluid, and grabbing assets from the workshop is brilliant - particularly for intersections. And on that matter, adding your own is so simple too. - Fantastic simulation. I don't really know how Simcity managed to get this wrong, when Cities gets it so right. Simcity's glassbox engine was cool to look at, I admit, but... In Simcity, people woke up in the morning, went to work at the nearest job they could find, then went to the nearest home they could find afterwards and repeated the same every morning. In Cities, every person has a name, a car, a house, a job... It's fantastic. Additionally, water simulation is pretty neat too. It's the only game where you can actually drain a river by pumping all the water out, or flood a city by building a dam. A few minor niggles that don't bother me at all, really: - I kinda miss the specialisation thing from Simcity. If, like me, you liked that, you'll probably miss it a bit too. - The graphics, while excellent, aren't quite as perfect as in Simcity. Something's a little off, so I think it just needs a few more settings in the options menu. However, you can pretty much have whater you like using mods too, so... not really much of an issue. - Traffic AI. Now, Simcity had the same problem at launch really. It's just not smart enough. The main problem is things like hearses, picking up jobs on the opposite side of the city, while there's a dead person waiting for transport right next to the crematorium. But, there's also problems with lanes. The AI just don't use them efficiently (even naturally) enough. Fix this. Please. - My train network gets jammed up. Not because of my rail design, but because of the rail design beyond the map, which seems a bit unfair.So, if you like city builders, I can't reccomend this game more. This is the new definitive city building game, and I think it'll remain that way for quite a while.9.999/10 (fix traffic for the 10/10)

content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												Hey look.... a city building game where I can build actual cities, instead of small towns, and I can even expand them!At first I was a little hesitant about buying the game, after being so dissapointed with the recent Simcity, but I bought the game none the less, and I am glad I did. Cities: Skylines have thus far been a very enjoyable experience. I have put just about 14 hours into the game, at the time of this review and I don't really have anything bad to say about the game.Gameplay:+ The difficulty feels just about right, and it seems to increase along with the size of your city.+ The game WILL punish you, if you make the wrong decisions, and let them be for too long.+ I enjoy having to balance my ever changing budget+ Even after 14 hours of gameplay, I still feel I have alot to discover about the game.- Having to delete abandoned buildings one by one, can be very tedious, boring and frustrating.- Upgrading and changing road types could work better.- Elevating roads, making bridges and then connectiong them to other roads can be a bit tricky.The game:+ The game runs smooth on my high-end rig+ The graphics are great considering the small download size+ The game seems to run Fullscreen (Windowed Mode) by default.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												My sister told me about this on release day.  I hadn't heard of it, but started to quite a lot soon thereafter.  I didn't research it at all - just bought it, knowing how well liked it was and basically what type of game it was.I started playing and, lo and behold, I JUST COULDN'T STOP!  It's one of those games, like the Civilization series, in which the hours fly by and you just want to do a little bit more before exiting.  And then some more hours disappear.  I played 12.7 hours in a single sitting!  Later while sleeping I dreamt I was playing it (and woke up feeling like I was having fun the whole night)!Suffice it to say - this game VERY fun and I should mention it's not too difficult to learn, but complex enough to keep you from getting bored.  I didn't watch videos to familiarize myself with it, but I did have to look up two questions I had in Google during my marathon.  That's not bad, right?  Afterwards, I finally thought I'd click on the icon in the upper left corner, which I had ignored the whole time.  That's when I realized where the resources could be found.  Now I'm going to tune up my city and make it greater than ever!I whole heartedly recommend Cities: Skylines.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												This is hands-down one of the finest city building games I have ever played.I've enjoyed games throughout the entire Simcity series (from 3000 on and excluding the newest) and on to smaller-scale management games such as the Anno series. Although these are good games, few have been as utterly absorbing as Cities: Skylines.The game is reasonably "easy" in the sense that you won't encounter a steep difficulty curve from the economic side of the simulation. That is, you're probably not going to run out of money, and before long your coffers will be so full you'll have more money than spending options.However, the real difficulty comes from the optimization, and it's baked into the game's design so organically that it makes you wonder why it hasn't been done before. If you want a large city with skyscrapers, you will have to get your services in your neighborhoods "just so" to get them to appear. You will hit population resistance points where you simply cannot grow unless you've optimized your layout, traffic, services, and so on.The traffic system can be a game unto itself, I found myself spending 45 minutes designing a complex "spaghetti bowl" traffic structure in the heart of my city, then watching and fine tuning it for the next hour or two by adding lanes, changing distances, or rerouting traffic to prevent jams. You can even watch the composition of traffic to get hints (lots of trucks means the industrial area is contributing too much traffic, etc.)You'll spend a lot of time looking, and then making small adjustments, but you won't mind thanks to the gorgeous diorama-style graphics.Simcity made it easy to get overzealous, and as your city grew you often found yourself "putting out fires" (sometimes literally) to keep it running, the larger the city, the more new wrinkles would show up that you would be constantly addressing. Cities: Skylines takes on a different style, moment-to-moment management of your city is reasonably relaxed, but if you want it to become a powerhouse metropolis, you'll have to master a number of systems and make it as efficient as possible. And then the traffic jams start...I can't recommend it highly enough for anyone looking for a relaxed city builder with enough depth there to chew on if you want it. It's a masterwork of game design and should be experienced by anyone with even a slight interest in city builders, and the Steam Workshop is well-integrated with loads of additional content available.

content:
Posted: October 17, 2015
												I've not come to Cities Skylines via Sim City like many reviewers here.I've always found the idea of City Simulators to be a bit dull, but after reading reviews on Steam and spotting a 50% discount, I took a leap of faith and boy was I impressed !! Building roads, housing, water, electricity, school, police, fire, trash, transportation etc. in such a beautiful sandbox is about as much fun as I 've had on a PC in years.  Making your population happy and making money for expansion is a surprisingly satisfying activity. Zoning, districts and council policies are all concepts which are introduced gradually without fuss or complication. The 3D game engine is spectacular, intuitive and gorgeous to look at.I had a two thousand citizen city after just a few hours and spent another couple with the game on 'pause' just admiring my creation.I'm months away from modding the game but already I can see huge replayability and value for money.Congratulations to development team - Cities Skylines is clearly a labour of love.I would recommend this game to everyone, especially town planners. (Sorry guys, I confess I used to think you lot were all wierdos!)Buy it.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												Eight hours in and I've been really enjoying it so far. It's very much inspired by the recent Sim City title (the UI is pretty much pulled directly from Sim City) but it makes some very important improvements. The cities are MUCH larger once your city grows and you can expand to additional squares. The game does a better job following individual citizens around the city. Also, the Steam Workshop support is great. There have already been a lot of neat mods and additional assets created and the game has only been out a few days. Also, the price point is better than Sim City's at launch, so that always helps too. If you were disappointed by EA/Maxis' title, check out this one instead. If you haven't played a city simulator game in a long time, this is the one I'd recommend picking up.

												The new standard in city-builders is here, brought to you by approximately 9 people.  BRAVO CO!!!!To those of you wondering if this game is not challenging enough for you compared to similarly-styled games, the answer damn well may be yes.  If you want something as "deep" as the SimCity series, give the modders a few months to crank out some difficulty adjustment mods and a disaster mod (currently there are no large-scale disasters in the game, just local fires, sickness, etc).  For $30, this game is an absolute steal - but it's going to get a LOT better in the next year as the modders dig their teeth in, so I wouldn't blame anyone for waiting til then to jump in.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2015
												Its been more than a decade but, 8 hours into the game, I think Simcity 4 finally has a worthy successor, Cities Skylines.This game offers;- A decent artstyle, the first decent replacement of the 2d Simcity style.- Much greater infrastructure detail, customisation & ease of use over SC4- The traffic model appears more realistic and your actions have logical impacts on it - Good modding support and tools- Whilst the scale, in terms of population, is much lower than SC4 it appears more realistic and accurate- I would estimate the maximum city size is 2x the size of the larger city tile in SC4The only negative thing I can say about the game is that it is very difficult to fail, however its something I'm willing to overlook. The unlocking of buildings/services/functions as your city progresses does not feel limiting but serves a vital role in ensuring less experienced/casual players find the game easier to play.90/100Only improvements I can think of would be;Adding a Region, allowing cities to interactAdding multiplayer region or easy way to exchange city tiles.I hope paradox will consider these improvements for the sequel, they are certainly on a distinguished road.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 14, 2015
												This game is phenomenal. Not since I first bought and downloaded Minecraft have I played one game for such a long period of time without switching to another game here or there. This game has the feel of a early RollerCoaster Tycoon game where you can tell the developers took pride in creating and perfecting every little detail and aspect of the game. This game is extremely addicting in the best way possible. Your city, the city that you watch rise out of a field of grass, feels alive. There is always a buzz around town and you truly feel like you and your civs are in it together. You feel a sense of obligation to your fellow city members after a while. If there is a traffic problem, you want to fix it for their sake and your own. After you fix that first problem, you look to improve another aspect of how your city is planned. After that, there is something else to improve. You can see why it is so hard to bank that final save of the night and hit that quit button. There are a few little things here and there that aren't perfect in the game yet. Some UI tweaks are needed and the driving AI is in need of an overhaul but for a game that was developed by a team of under 20 people a few minor issues are to be expected. I've seen blockbuster titles being released with more issues than this game. Mod support is incredible in this game as well. I've never seen such a seamless integration with the steam workshop in a game. If there is an issue that you have with an aspect of this game, there is very likely a mod that will change it for you.I would say I have definitely gotten my money's worth out of this game already and I don't intend on putting it down in the near future. I can only say thank you to a development team that deserves the high praise that this game has garnered. I can only hope that they keep making games that are as simple yet deep with gameplay as Cities: Skylines in the future.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2015
												This is a great game. Sim City 4 will still always hold a special place in my heart but this one comes very close, if not with the flaws of Sim City 4 balanced out with this game, it's the same.The game is fluid. I've had a city with almost 100k residents and no lag moving around the city and taking care of things. the game is a bit more challenging though...don't have the right balance of services and your city and you'll crap out. the flaws of this game:* As mentioned, if you don't have the right balance of things your city will fail, and fast. While laying new subway lines for my CBD my population went from around 15k to around 5k. Turns out that portion of my city randomly died, and fast. I then discovered that I had a minor traffic jam in which ambulances were waiting for a red light! One of the major flaws of the game: The emergancy services don't ignore the traffic lights when they're responding to calls - this makes major problems if you have a minor traffic jam, your ambulences are stuck waiting in it and your citizens die.* More onto the above point, if you have a well established public transportation system, 90% of the vehicles on your roadway are AMBULENCES! This is SO annoying. If you need to get precise, no matter where you zoom, you hear the sirens! EVERYONE in your city will call 911 if they have a bloody nose it seems! THIS IS SO ANNOYING.* The landfills have to be placed in the midst of your city, you can't just shove them off in one corner and have your garbage trucks carry the garbage all that way. This is a major problem as the landfills cause ground pollution. Probably not that badly as an incinerator, but with ground pollution near to your residents they'll get sick.* The onramps/offramps look a bit weird and are hard to manage, same with the curves of the roads. Not a game breaker though.All in all, I definitely recommend you get this game. It's fantastic, and with a HUGE modding community already going, it'll only get better.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												You can tell when a game is created by passionate artists and developers. This could be the SimCity 4 successor that we have been waiting all these years for. Everything that SC2k13 did wrong, Colossal Order tried to make right. City sizes are 9x bigger, and easily modded to 25x bigger than SC2k13. They didn't only make things better, they also introduced many new features such as districts, specialized industrial zones and dynamic water movement. Modding support is also a huge feature that is offered. The Steam Workshop has over 1000 mods, models and maps already online less than 24 hours after the release. There are a handful of requests for features that didn't make it to release, but the devs promised that they would continue working on this game to include as many new features as possible. (Such as road & highway tunnels, disasters and day/night cycles).This is only the first day of the launch, and the game is already extremely stable, and looks beautiful.I look forward to seeing what the devs and the mod community comes up with in the future!This game was created by a small indie development team and look at what they produced. I highly recommend this game to anyone who felt disappointed with SimCity and wants to play a genuine city simulator that has the fun of previous versions, but the new features that modern gamers want to play.

												This is what SimCity should have been. Instead of shoehorning in city specializations to make up for the tiny cities, this lets you build GIGANTIC, sprawling cities (especially with mods), where traffic and transit flow is hugely important. Even with the unlimited money cheat, this game is surprisingly difficult to master, but it always feels like your actions have an effect. content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												I'm going to say right now that I absolutely love this game and I'm addicted and I'm most likely in the top 10-ish percent of the people with the highest amount of hours put into the game. Now, the pros and cons then the verdict.ProsNo need to be online (unless you're getting mods or assets)Very good road system with okay traffic AIInsane amount of possibilities for road intersections as well as rail and metro intersectionsNot SimCity 2015Large selection of mods that can improve this already amazing gameHuge maps that are over 9 times the size of SimCity's (25x or even 81x with mods)Worked on launch dayVery good sense of progression via unlocks and just seeing your city riseThe game looks incredible and can look even better with modsGiant amount of assets available that range from Suburbanhouses to huge statues and highrisesInsane levels of detailMuch, much more but I want to get back to playing XDConsDefault traffic AI is a bit wonky (can be fixed with mods)A few glitchs (paths going underground, Roads working incorrectly)Some assets may have low quality resolutionsSome mods can almost break your gameKeep in mind that the mods and assets cannot be controlled by the devs so it's not their fault that some are a bit low quality.Final Verdict9.5/10This game is a must have and I don't regret spending any of my hours in this game.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Finally a game that can rival SimCity 4! Or so I thought. While there is a lot to like here I have some long standing frustrations that still haven't been fully dealt with. The largest by far is the traffic. For goodness sake use ALL the lanes! I'm tired of seeing a huge line of cars in the right lane of a 6 lane road and all of them are going straight. The AI needs a much better system to deciding where the cars should be. This might seem a minor issue (and it was for the most part in SimCity 4), but in Cities Skylines having cars stuck in traffic has a huge negative impact on your service trucks. Very quickly you have the dead overwhelming areas because the traffic is stacked up in one lane. It's irritating and I find myself really only playing the game in bursts. Usually after a new DLC or patch comes out in hopes the various minor things are fixed.Bottom line though... it's really the only strong city builder out there. Its performance exceeds that of Cities XL and XXL and EA just ruined SimCity.

Now onto the review.The city of Dinosys was faring quite well, it's many citizens bustling about, families had enjoyed themselves and basked in the city's modest taxes and ample parks services, industry toiling away producing superior "Made in Dinotopia" goods at a competitive global market rate.Little did the mayor realize, that the placements of too many sewage outtake pipes in a single spot, had reversed the flow of water back into the pump stations.  The city was in trouble, they tried to mitigate the damage by running a new municipal campaign entitled: "What can brown do for you?  Dinosys' new drinking fad!"  Unfortunately people did not buy it, people left in droves, and those that stayed, welcomed the sweet french kiss of death.TWELVE YEARS.  since SimCity 4 released, the city building fans have waited twelve years for this game.  It is everything that should have been, but now is done right.  Water physics simulation, home permanence for your citizens (unless they die), expandable map size, and.. oh yes..  OFFLINE MODE. Does this game have it's quirks? Yes.  traffic not yielding to emergency vehicles, traffic piling up on one lane while the other lane sits empty, and airplane paths that tend to ignore mountains, and the twitter analogue; Chirper.  Many hate on it, but I use it as a tool, to find the people responsible for tweeting negatively about my mayoral methods, and ENDING THEM.  #NOHOME4U!But that's the niggly bits that will get fixed as time goes on.  At it's core, this game is FUN,

content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												Great game so far. I stayed away from SimCity 2013 after hearing all the bad reviews, although I enjoyed SimCity 4 a great deal. Being able to customize assets with a neat in game tool is pretty sweet. Having the game be very open towards modding is a huge plus too, and hopefully the developers will update the game frequently with bug fixes and new features.What the game should improve on/add -- Population and job density: After upgrading low density commerce and residential to high density (which at first looks like the equivalent of medium density buildings from SimCity 4), the increase in jobs and population per building is quite low. The city I have right now has a decent amount of medium high rises, yet sits only at around 10,000 population. If I had built this city in SimCity 4 I would probably have around double the population I do in Cities: Skylines. I'm sure some modders will fix this, but it would be nice to be fixed in vanilla too.- Allow for roads to be dragged across other roads: Currently if I want to build a 4 lane street and connect across multiple 2 lane streets, I have to drag and connect to the first one, then stop, click again and connect to the 2nd, since if you try to simply drag them across all the roads at once the game brings up the "space in use" error. - The graphics: Yes I know graphics aren't everything, and I don't need an amazing looking game for the game to be fun. My beef with the graphics is that the buildings and terrain have this blurry feel to them most of the time, which is acceptable viewing them from a distance, but up close they should be pretty clear to the camera. - The cars: In my opinion they look too plain and generic. Yes they have different colors and types, but for the most part they honestly look like those colored cars from The Game of Life board game. More realistic and detailed cars would be nice to see.- Ability to drive around your city, akin to the U-Drive-It mode from SimCity 4. Definitely not necessary to add in the game, but would be neat to drive around the city, either first person or 3rd person. 1st person would be much cooler, but 3rd person would be easier to code in most likely.Overall I would recommend getting this game if you like city builders. I wouldn't give it a perfect score, as the population/job density issue is really bugging me, but that'll likely get fixed.

content:
Posted: January 23
												Cities Skylines still remains one of the best city builders available in terms of flexibility, available space, mods, and so on.In terms of available space you get a gigantic 9 tile area to work in by default. Which can be expanded with the 25 tile unlock mod. Since maps are different and inevitably cities get built different every time you play you don't unlock these tiles in any particular order either. You just purchase any tile that is next to another tile you already own. Which means you are not locked down to a simple square.There is a LOT of community content now. The game has been out for a while and the workshop is full of mods, maps, and assets to make your game better.  Of course I always recommend first play throughs be straight up vanilla just to get a feel for the unmodded a game. However, there are some real benefits to using mods.That said though I really can not recommend any of the paid DLCs other than After Dark. This was the first DLC they released and it still seems like the most impactful to date. I would have to say that what makes it better is that it provides things that are useful in building the city or in managing the city. This would be, as example, like the Bus Terminal which is an almost necessary thing for managing your city. Using it you can easily see how many of your citizens will travel between your various routes.Snowfall and Natural Disasters on the other hand always seemed, to me at least, more gimmicky than really helpful. Like they were just put in to say "here is new content. enjoy!" but they really didnt help anything like After Dark did.  The Snowfall DLC pretty much only gives you the street car (tram) service to help with actually managing your city and everything else is just winter flavored Skylines. Actually one might even say that Snowfall is more hassle that its worth since you have to build in an all white zone which people have complained many times about this causing eye strain and headaches. Then you have specialized services for heating and road maintenance which eats up more of your city resources than you normally would.Natural Disasters is kinda one of those things i remember from the first SimCity game I played as a kid. I remember working on my city and having the a tornado or godzilla go through the city and destroy things. Then I would have to rebuild. Seemed like might be interesting. Not so much though to be honest.Where in that old game when you didnt have much else to worry about except placing power lines and roads... this game you have a lot more to worry about. Probably the least threatening aspect here is the forest fires, but everything else if it hits your city can really be a problem. The thing I find the worst about this, and I have seen this thought elsewhere too, is that I have to spend so many hours building up a great city then a disaster comes and smashes things. Which I am not even one that goes overboard with a huge amount of detail! I have seen streamers that really micromanage on the details and if I put that level of detail in only to have it destroyed I would quit playing.Mass Transit Will be coming out soon and it promises to be another good DLC that will be helpful in many ways. What is known about it right now is that there will be new public transportation added in the paid DLC which will help in managing the city better and the free patch that goes along with the DLC release will have a LOT of quality of life changes which are focused on traffic and transportation.Here is a run down of the DLC content:After Dark:Added PrisonsAdded District Specializations (Industry and Commercial)Added Taxi ServiceAdded Bus Terminal (handles multiple bus lines where citizens can go to change between lines)Added Bicycles and Bicycle Pathssee the full patch here: http://www.skylineswiki.com/Patch_1.2.0Snow Fall:Added Winter ThemeAdded Tram ServiceAdded Snow Plow (only on snow maps obviously)Added more energy consumption and heating requirements (..on the snow maps)see the full patch here: http://www.skylineswiki.com/Patch_1.3.0-f4Natural Disasters:Added 7 DisastersAdded Early Warning System (to warn you about disasters happening)Added Helicopter (fire, medical, and police)Added Evacuation Routes (for disaster events)see the full patch here: http://www.skylineswiki.com/Patch_1.6.0Mass Transit:Added MonorailsAdded BlimpsAdded Cable CarsAdded FerriesAdded Transport Hubs (multi-transit buildings ex. monorail+bus terminal)see the full patch here: TBA

content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												SimCity was one of the very first games I was ever really hooked on.  I vividly remember building cities in black-and-white on my dad's office Macintosh.  Since then I've jumped on pretty much any game that claims to be city-builder-ish.  And not since SimCity 4, over a decade ago, have I had this much fun building a city from scratch.The scale of the space you can build in is great.  Starting with 2km x 2km and eventually expanding out to 9km^2, you can build truly massive cities. What makes that scale even better is you can really divide up your metropolis in a number of ways.  From districts that can have individualized govt policies (legal pot, smoke detector ditribution), to localized city services that aren't connected to the larger grid.  The game gives you a ton of room to experiment.The one big challenge though you'll face is transportation.  Building an effecient city grid of roads, public transit, trains & subways that doesn't have terrible choke points is difficult.  Use of elevated bypasses, rail corridors etc are difficult to plan as you don't get access to them until an hour or more into a game, so you may find yourself abandoning your initial city area to build up things "properly" in a newly opened plot of land, then going back and bulldozing your original downtown to start it over again.Beyond the traffic challenge, it can at times be difficult to know why your city isn't growing.  Sometimes demand drops to 0 for no apparant reason, then 5 minutes later skyrockets again.  There's obviously something going on that's pushing down demand, but as a player it's hard to figure out some times.  A few patches to improve UI and reporting will no doubt solve this issue.In the end, the traffic planning and the simulation feedback issues are pretty minor in the face of what's probably the most fun city sim since the glory days of Maxis.  And at what I'd consider a "budget" price point, if you're a fan of the genre, this is a must-buy game.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												This is hands-down one of the finest city building games I have ever played.I've enjoyed games throughout the entire Simcity series (from 3000 on and excluding the newest) and on to smaller-scale management games such as the Anno series. Although these are good games, few have been as utterly absorbing as Cities: Skylines.The game is reasonably "easy" in the sense that you won't encounter a steep difficulty curve from the economic side of the simulation. That is, you're probably not going to run out of money, and before long your coffers will be so full you'll have more money than spending options.However, the real difficulty comes from the optimization, and it's baked into the game's design so organically that it makes you wonder why it hasn't been done before. If you want a large city with skyscrapers, you will have to get your services in your neighborhoods "just so" to get them to appear. You will hit population resistance points where you simply cannot grow unless you've optimized your layout, traffic, services, and so on.The traffic system can be a game unto itself, I found myself spending 45 minutes designing a complex "spaghetti bowl" traffic structure in the heart of my city, then watching and fine tuning it for the next hour or two by adding lanes, changing distances, or rerouting traffic to prevent jams. You can even watch the composition of traffic to get hints (lots of trucks means the industrial area is contributing too much traffic, etc.)You'll spend a lot of time looking, and then making small adjustments, but you won't mind thanks to the gorgeous diorama-style graphics.Simcity made it easy to get overzealous, and as your city grew you often found yourself "putting out fires" (sometimes literally) to keep it running, the larger the city, the more new wrinkles would show up that you would be constantly addressing. Cities: Skylines takes on a different style, moment-to-moment management of your city is reasonably relaxed, but if you want it to become a powerhouse metropolis, you'll have to master a number of systems and make it as efficient as possible. And then the traffic jams start...I can't recommend it highly enough for anyone looking for a relaxed city builder with enough depth there to chew on if you want it. It's a masterwork of game design and should be experienced by anyone with even a slight interest in city builders, and the Steam Workshop is well-integrated with loads of additional content available.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												(Note: This is essentially my review script I used for my video review, so some of this review may sound strange without the video accompaniment) 


YouTube™ Video: KTG Reviews: Cities: Skylines | Is It Worth It? 

			Views: 248		

			Just something different I thought I'd try. So join me as I endeavor to answer, is it worth it? If you enjoy my videos please hit that like button and consider subscribing!		

Fans of city simulation games have bore an itch that has not been scratched. I’ve felt that itch as well, waiting for a quality successor to one of my favorite simulation games, and possibly one of my favorite games I had growing up. That game is SimCity 4. Since SimCity 4 came out in 2003, there has been no game that I felt was worthy of being called it’s successor. Games like Cities: XL and even Maxis’s own SimCity (which came out in 2013) have failed to produce an experience like the ever popular SimCity 4.Cities: Skylines (Which has no relation to the CitiesXL Franchise) is from the makers of the Cities in Motion franchise, a series focused primarily on managing a cities traffic. And funnily enough traffic is one of the few things I believe this game struggles with, but we’ll discuss that later.So first, lets just have a quick overview of the game.After a brief loading screen which provides you with a few random tips and tricks, you’ll be presented with your map. And a message, on the bottom right that serves as a basic and unintrusive tutorial.I generally don’t care for pop-up text tutorials, but I think colossal order did a good job, the tutorial is simple to skip and disable, as well as read and understand, and it doesn’t impact your game in a negative way.In order to build anything you will need a connection with the outside world. You do this by simply selecting the road, being presented with another easy to understand tutorial, and clicking and dragging the road to its desired length. Simple enough right? It’s been done this way in nearly every city sim I’ve ever played, it works, so it doesn’t need fixing. I think that is the same approach colossal order took while developing this game. They took everything that works in a city builder, and put it in the game. For the most part they succeeded. And where they may have failed, both in opinion and reality, users are empowered via to the Steam Workshop to create the game experience they want.This is all they had to do! This is all maxis and ea had to do to create an experience that will last a long time. Simply take what people liked from SimCity 4 and move it into the next generation of modern computing. Thats it.Now, this isn’t to say Cities: Skylines doesn’t have its faults, because it certainly does.There are some minor ones, graphically the game isn’t stunning. There are no filters and it’s just kind of grey. Although the included color correction tool in the options menu may change the visual styling more to your liking, it is very limiting only providing you with 4 options. Perhaps this can be rectified with mods, in fact it may have already been, considering there are over 30,000 mods as of this review.Another gripe I had was the lack of variety in buildings. From a distance this isn’t so noticeable, but zoom in to any one neighborhood, and you will be presented with a plethora of identical looking homes. Both in appearance and color palate. Additionally, the lack of any disaster mechanic such as what you’d find in the SimCity series is disappointing. It could have been a great way to make cities more memorable. Which brings me to another point.Often times I’d find myself playing this game for several hours in one sitting, building a city up from nothing, to a thriving megalopolis. Only to abandon the city the next day I play simply because my cities don’t feel special to me. Perhaps its just a failing of my personal style of play, or perhaps its a strike against Cities: Skylines.One of the primary issues you encounter is traffic. Traffic management quickly becomes your primary concern once your city begins to grow. It is unclear to me if this was by design or simply an undesired consequence of how the game handles “agents.” What I mean by agents is that every single moving speck, also known as your citizens, has a purpose or function, they aren’t simply randomly moving around the city with no purpose. Every delivery truck has a destination and source, just as every citizen has a job and a home. What this means, is that without careful traffic management and planning, you can experience bottlenecks, due to either your own incompetence or perhaps just how the game handles traffic, which seems to direct traffic based on the shortest distance available, and doesn’t take into account congestion.There are some other smaller gripes I have, but traffic is by far the biggest antagonist I have seen. Which brings me to another point. Beyond traffic, there is really not any end goal or ongoing metric that you have to manage. Which can turn some people off if they are looking for the game to tell them what to do, which it really doesn’t. There are some achievements or milestones, based on population which unlock new services. But these stop after 80,000 population. Meaning if you’re playing just to unlock everything, congratulations, you’ve just done it.In addition to milestones as an ongoing goal, you can also unlock unique buildings, which are earned by meeting certain requirements. For example, once your city has the airport, you can unlock the Grand Mall, which improves metrics like tourism, attractiveness and entertainment. But again, this is really all there is if you’re looking for a sense of progression. You have to create your own milestones if you really want to enjoy this game to its fullest extent. But even then, you are not experiencing all this game has to offer.The best way to play this game is with mods. There are a myriad of mods, which promise to fix nearly every problem I have encountered.A mod fixed the obnoxious color of pollution in the water and ground. A mod let me correct the direction of my roads without the need to delete and replace them. They have added in game terraforming, they allow me to place roads on top of roads. In short the possibilities of this game, as well as it’s long term viability are essentially endless. Thanks to the modding support provided by the devs, and the catalyst that is the steam workshop, making the installation of these mod files painless.This is the game that may very well dethrone what is often considered the definitive city builder, SimCity 4.Now, there's simply the matter of answering the original question I posed at the beginning of this video: Is it worth it?Despite it’s minor failings with traffic management and building variety, I think I can confidently say that this game is indeed worth the bargain price of $29.99.

												This game does what SimCity should have done.  This game is a smooth-running city simulator with (next to) no fluff added. Posted: June 19, 2015
												I'm going to say right now that I absolutely love this game and I'm addicted and I'm most likely in the top 10-ish percent of the people with the highest amount of hours put into the game. Now, the pros and cons then the verdict.ProsNo need to be online (unless you're getting mods or assets)Very good road system with okay traffic AIInsane amount of possibilities for road intersections as well as rail and metro intersectionsNot SimCity 2015Large selection of mods that can improve this already amazing gameHuge maps that are over 9 times the size of SimCity's (25x or even 81x with mods)Worked on launch dayVery good sense of progression via unlocks and just seeing your city riseThe game looks incredible and can look even better with modsGiant amount of assets available that range from Suburbanhouses to huge statues and highrisesInsane levels of detailMuch, much more but I want to get back to playing XDConsDefault traffic AI is a bit wonky (can be fixed with mods)A few glitchs (paths going underground, Roads working incorrectly)Some assets may have low quality resolutionsSome mods can almost break your gameKeep in mind that the mods and assets cannot be controlled by the devs so it's not their fault that some are a bit low quality.Final Verdict9.5/10This game is a must have and I don't regret spending any of my hours in this game.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												You can tell when a game is created by passionate artists and developers. This could be the SimCity 4 successor that we have been waiting all these years for. Everything that SC2k13 did wrong, Colossal Order tried to make right. City sizes are 9x bigger, and easily modded to 25x bigger than SC2k13. They didn't only make things better, they also introduced many new features such as districts, specialized industrial zones and dynamic water movement. Modding support is also a huge feature that is offered. The Steam Workshop has over 1000 mods, models and maps already online less than 24 hours after the release. There are a handful of requests for features that didn't make it to release, but the devs promised that they would continue working on this game to include as many new features as possible. (Such as road & highway tunnels, disasters and day/night cycles).This is only the first day of the launch, and the game is already extremely stable, and looks beautiful.I look forward to seeing what the devs and the mod community comes up with in the future!This game was created by a small indie development team and look at what they produced. I highly recommend this game to anyone who felt disappointed with SimCity and wants to play a genuine city simulator that has the fun of previous versions, but the new features that modern gamers want to play.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												A real return to city building greatness. I approached Cites:Skylines with a small amount of trepidation, I have already been burnt by the disappointment that was the most recent Sim City. However Cities:Skylines is no Sim City clone. Rather it takes a lot of the best elements of the Sim City franchise, and puts them into a very a slick, playable and user friendly package.  The game is friendly to a new user, introducing new elements and features over time in a gated sense, but don't be mistaken it isn't impossible to fail, on my very first city I managed to bankrupt myself before I had proper infrastructure or even a few buildings because of my complex and excessively ambitious waste management and water system. From the get go there is a lot to do providing an engaging experience, but not so much as to overwhelm. There is enough detail and content to introduce the newer player gradually whilst  simultaneously allowing players with more experience new ways to improve and experiment. You start off small, with a few roads and your very most basic amenities and infrastructure for water and electricity. You attract a few hundred people, build a school, and start expanding your commercial center. Before you know it you are the mayor of a town of 50,000, rebuilding motorways, managing 6 lane roundabouts and trying to build a spaghetti roller-coaster of a highway junction to alleviate excessive congestion as traffic pours into your Metropolis to visit your colossal skyscrapers. It is a very satisfying experience, through your own strategy and planning you have turned a small dull field with a few small houses into a buzzing, noisy city with a real character of your own choosing. Despite how enjoyable the game has been so far in the short term, my most considerable worry going into the future is the potential lack of replay value. You build your infrastructure , you grow your city, you put amenities and services. The play pattern every game is pretty much identical, and there are very few randomly generated elements to change this. Combined with the lack of multiplayer capability really begs the question what will keep players coming back for more. However this is certainly somewhat alleviated by the games innate modability and interaction with the steam workshop, which seems to add a lot of capability and even quality of life fixes to the game. This game has such a low price-tag that you could easily get your value for money in a few play throughs, and even if  you do get burnt out there is not much to lose. The game also has all of the appropriate attributes to evolve and grow with the release of DLC and steam workshop content, making it a really appealing prospect to come back to when you feel like a spending your time building a city.The game is fairly slow tempo by design, this shouldn't be a surprise it's being a  city builder not Call of Duty. If slower simulation games (Civilization, city management games, Rome Total War etc) are not to you preference then I can't really suggest this will do much to change that. It's a great game for relaxing, and thinking, but its not high tempo competitive nor challenging game. Though that does not mean it isn't engaging,  there is always something to do and things ever changing as you grow your city, it always keeps the player considering of ways to improve/diversify or grow the city.The lack of multiplayer is a missed opportunity. Had the game had similar multiplayer functionality to the most recent Sim City, such as if there was some way of building concurrent cities that would evolve and change depending on a friend''s decisions in real time would have made for an even more complete experience. At the very least better functionality in terms of sharing cities and visiting cities created by friends would add a lot discussion and interaction, but  I imagine these  features are possibilities for the future, the game itself is a great platform which could be easily extended to a mutliplayer experience which I feel would round off the experience and add significant longevity.  Conclusion4/5. A very good city building simulation that is very accessible, with a user friendly and functional UI and variable gameplay pacing. The game is simultaneously relaxing yet intriguing, and ultimately leaves the player feel very satisfied. The steam workshop, and other modability means the game may continue to grow, but the static gameplay pattern with very little variability or random events and no current multiplayer make the longevity questionable.

content:
Posted: October 17, 2015
												I've not come to Cities Skylines via Sim City like many reviewers here.I've always found the idea of City Simulators to be a bit dull, but after reading reviews on Steam and spotting a 50% discount, I took a leap of faith and boy was I impressed !! Building roads, housing, water, electricity, school, police, fire, trash, transportation etc. in such a beautiful sandbox is about as much fun as I 've had on a PC in years.  Making your population happy and making money for expansion is a surprisingly satisfying activity. Zoning, districts and council policies are all concepts which are introduced gradually without fuss or complication. The 3D game engine is spectacular, intuitive and gorgeous to look at.I had a two thousand citizen city after just a few hours and spent another couple with the game on 'pause' just admiring my creation.I'm months away from modding the game but already I can see huge replayability and value for money.Congratulations to development team - Cities Skylines is clearly a labour of love.I would recommend this game to everyone, especially town planners. (Sorry guys, I confess I used to think you lot were all wierdos!)Buy it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												SimCity was one of the very first games I was ever really hooked on.  I vividly remember building cities in black-and-white on my dad's office Macintosh.  Since then I've jumped on pretty much any game that claims to be city-builder-ish.  And not since SimCity 4, over a decade ago, have I had this much fun building a city from scratch.The scale of the space you can build in is great.  Starting with 2km x 2km and eventually expanding out to 9km^2, you can build truly massive cities. What makes that scale even better is you can really divide up your metropolis in a number of ways.  From districts that can have individualized govt policies (legal pot, smoke detector ditribution), to localized city services that aren't connected to the larger grid.  The game gives you a ton of room to experiment.The one big challenge though you'll face is transportation.  Building an effecient city grid of roads, public transit, trains & subways that doesn't have terrible choke points is difficult.  Use of elevated bypasses, rail corridors etc are difficult to plan as you don't get access to them until an hour or more into a game, so you may find yourself abandoning your initial city area to build up things "properly" in a newly opened plot of land, then going back and bulldozing your original downtown to start it over again.Beyond the traffic challenge, it can at times be difficult to know why your city isn't growing.  Sometimes demand drops to 0 for no apparant reason, then 5 minutes later skyrockets again.  There's obviously something going on that's pushing down demand, but as a player it's hard to figure out some times.  A few patches to improve UI and reporting will no doubt solve this issue.In the end, the traffic planning and the simulation feedback issues are pretty minor in the face of what's probably the most fun city sim since the glory days of Maxis.  And at what I'd consider a "budget" price point, if you're a fan of the genre, this is a must-buy game.

content:
Posted: March 22, 2015
												*Edited for patch 1.1Unlike the disappointment that was SimCity 2013, Cities: Skylines is a real city simulator/builder. Every single resident in your city has a home, a job, an education (if you build schools that is), and everyone has somewhere they need to go. You can watch them leave their home, take the subway to the bus stop to take the bus to the mall, and then do the same in reverse to go back home. As someone who fell in love with SimCity when the original came out as shareware in 1989 and have played every Will Wright game since (as well as some of the none-Will Wright followups), I highly recommend Cities: Skylines to anyone who likes city builders. This game is what we wanted from a new SimCity game, without all the bad decisions EA made.The game isn't perfect, but it's pretty damn close. It makes building truly massive cities fun and possible, and with the right hardware the cities look pretty good too with an incredible attention to detail. Building a succesful (profitable) city is fairly easy (easier than SC4 that is), but getting past the 50,000 resident mark, while dealing with traffic, water, power, garbage, and sewage is the real challenge. Getting past the 100,000 resident mark requires some creative thinking in the construction of intersections, highways, and bus lines, but it can be done and you can keep expanding your city until you run out of land to purchase.While the game is a true simulation, it has no natural disasters and if you can keep your city from dying to polluted water or choking in traffic jams, then you can continue building until the budget can't cover it anymore.Traffic has been improved greatly since launch and is now much easier to manage. We've gotten tunnels and the ability to build roundabouts and any other kind of road or rail at any level above and below ground, and the game continues to have some of the best mod support of any game ever released.

content:
Posted: March 25, 2015
												Do you want to build and manage a glorious city? The latest SimCity game didn't give you what you wanted?Look no further, Cities: Skylines is there to sate your needs.- Plenty of ways to build and manage your city- Good variety of city customization options- Compelling and refreshing gameplay- "Easy to learn, hard to master"- Extensive modding support and toolsThis game hasn't been out for a long time at the time of this review but already I dare say this is the best citybuilding game in years. In Cities: Skylines you are responsible to build and manage a city (obviously) and you are given the tools, many tools, to help you in your adventure.Created by the team behind the Cities in Motion games, this game is made by people knowing the genre and this isn't hard to notice. Cities: Skylines features a solid range of tools to make the city you desire, in my opinion far outmatching other games in the genre such as SimCity 5/2013 (given this title was quite horrible to begin with).You build, manage and expand an ever demanding city, capable of surviving on its own. In Cities: Skylines, you are given plenty of options and ways to customize your own city to your heart's desire. With the ability to create districts you can name certain regions of the city as you please and furthermore, even add policies to that specific district or to the entire city. For example, you can ban heavy traffic passing through a peaceful suburban community, making your citizens happier or assign specified industrial areas to promote farming, improving your income from that district.The ability to customize the city goes in depth, if you want you can even rename your city's inhabitants, houses or even cars, if you're into that.As for the core citybuilding itself, it offers solid mechanics and an appealing visual style that should interest every gamer liking the citybuilding genre. Cities: Skylines offers a reasonably sized area to begin with, which seems to be larger than certain other games in the same genre, but when it comes to size this isn't the most impressive: As your city grows, you become able to buy new zones adjecent to your current area, expanding the city. In total, you can create a city nine times the size of the starting map.Not only the size of the map is a big feat of the fame, its mechanics regarding transportation, water and electricity supplies, education, law enforcement and others is well laid out and the city will change for better or worse depending on your urban planning skills. If you want, you can even build a dam to supply your city with the power it needs to flourish. (Though beware, you don't want to have your city upstream of where the dam will be, the reason why should be obvious.)The last thing I'll discuss is one of the best additions to the game, in my honest opinion at least, is the modding support.Cities: Skylines offers great in-game tools to customize the base game to your own desires. With the in-game tools you can not only design your own maps but you can easily design your own buildings, parks or road areas using either existing in-game props or by converting images into the game. If you can't be bothered making your own assets or "mods", feel free to browse the Steam Workshop, barely two weeks after launch and this game already features a massive amount of player-made content including several cool and beautiful assets as well as entirely custom made maps (In this case I refer to the GTA: V map 'mod', which displays the game's map remarkably accurate.)All in all, there is nothing that I would critize about this game, it's a solid citybuilder with extensive customization tools, Cities: Skylines is my personal favourite citybuilding game of the last decade.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 9, 2016
												Recommended purchase.The idea behind other city simulations finally done better in every aspect. Additionally deep, but not overwhelming, and complex, but not complicated, with a well designed and easy to use and accessible UI. Simply endless fun.If you are looking for city simulators, you can look at all the others - you found the best one here with Cities: Skylines, no doubt and by far.Now, a year after release, there is even a whole scene of YouTubers, who use the unlimited money mod of this game and spend all their time mainly with the design features of the in-game city editor and who then use the city simulation component of the game only to bring life to the backdrop of their creations - much like building a model railroad, only in your computer and way cooler.If you want to just casually play a few hours and create a small town, or if you intend to go deeper into the concepts, that depends practically only on you, on what you want to do with the game. Both seems to be possible with the game, for one part probably because of the game's accessibility.I've bought it shortly after release, about a year ago, and unfortunately didn't play with it since (only 20hrs seeing if it works), until recently.Now, after a three week vacation, one year and two DLC packs later, I can see bazillions of workshop items to enhance the game, tutorials of varying depth and orientation on video platforms and in written form on Steam/reddit/imgur, that can help mastering the challenges of the game with less experimenting and more method and intent from your side. A lot of people have shared their experiences online, go look..During these past three weeks I've spent about 40 more hours with Cities: Skylines, additionally about 10 hours of reading up on actual urban planning science and watching a number of videos from more experienced gamers. Yes, Cities: Skylines is a game, and because of that it is of course a simplified version of reality. The game's challenges are still very much oriented in the real world challenges of urban planning and you can actually verify your own ideas on how to solve any of these situations of growth and tackle the multicausal nature of your city situation.Also, probably because the game's background simulation is much more complex under the hood than it may seem on the surface, every city you may create is an individual bunch of problems and you'll never find any magic bullet solution for any of your problems anywhere. It's amazing to see how playing the game more systematically can enhance your world view.There's usually far more than one way to do things in the game, the creators seem to have encouraged this by their game design and also seem to have encouraged the community to be creative and enhance the game with mods. Under the hood of the game everything looks fairly modern, my fast i7 4GHz gaming rig is actually doing some work here and I haven't even reached the 2^16 simulation agent limit, yet.Anyway, because of its fine surface polish, low price, peaceful and educationally valuable content, this game can be recommended to anyone anyway. It's a fine game no questions asked, no matter for who or how you look at it. It think there can be not much substantial doubt in this. That's why I thought I'd owe this game at least a review, as it is a masterpiece in every aspect I can think of. And I think it was not just one head who created this game, it feels like many people put their best together successfully to create this game.It's especially recommended for people, who look for more than just a timesink and it can probably easily be like that. I think, I'm learning a lot for my life, like multitasking, making better decisions, being more disciplined - just by playing this game. A perfect gift.There's just one other game I know of that I could easily spend hundreds of hours with, and already did. Cities: Skylines is another one in this rare kind.I'm really amazed by what Colossal Order created here and I'm thankful for their efforts. It delivers on pretty much everything I've been waiting for since 1989 and more. Thank you!

												I'm not usually a fan of city builder type games, so I only bought Cities: Skylines because it had modding support so I could fix anything I didn't like. Strange thing is I haven't modded Cities: Skylines yet. I've played this game a lot more than my time in game shows because I play on the Linux version on my laptop which never gets a net connection. I don't know if this game was a labour of love but it does have the 'feel' of something created with real care and attention to detail to me and that is quite a rare feeling for me to get while gaming these days. So yes, I like Cities: Skylines a lot. It's about the right level of difficulty so I can relax and watch my city evolve while planning what to do next. The learning curve is quite steady, but there is a level of complexity that does require good planning and observation especially for transportation.

content:
Posted: April 25
												Cities: Skylines is an amazing city builder game. You don't just place the appropriate buildings to gain their benefit as in other, more plain, city builders. In Cities: Skylines you actually need to plan your city logically. Traffic, pollution, healthcare, deathcare, fire safety, police safety, and disaster safety all matter.A city can be crippled poorly designed intersection(s) and logistics. This can lead to several outcomes. A fire may take out your industry if fire trucks cannot reach the location. Pollution can make people sick. If these sick people die they must be taken to a cemetary. I think it is fun to design cities that effectively mitigate most of these things. Each gameplay is different for me. This is especially true if you play with random disasters. I would recommend this as it certainly adds character to your city and its design.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												My specs: Lenovo Y580, gtx 660M, i7-3630QM @2.4GHz, I should mention I'm not a big city builder fan, past exp has been some simcity game 20yrs ago and er...Theme Hospital XD.Pro:+ No online/server/login problems;+ Easy to pickup and start building;+ Vehicles don't suddenly disappear, you can follow them to their destination;+ Great attention to detail, can name anything from people, vehicles, buildings, etc;+ Great visuals, can zoom in/out and follow vehicles;+ Not overcomplicated with stats, graphs, etc;+ Relaxing game, no disasters or anything trying to ruin your city;+ Mods/Workshop, Map and Asset editor already added;+ Freedom to build simple or insanely complex road system;+ Just a well developed game;Cons:- Needs a fast machine to enjoy graphics;- Might not be enough depth for hardcore sim builders;- Will eat a lot of yr time;- No wind pollution;Colossal Order have done a great job in creating a great city builder. There is a huge amount of content already in the base game. Deluxe edition doesn't contain much in game enhancements but if you have the money and don't mind showing your appreciation you should. They have put in everything from the basics of water and elec to build complex road systems, residential, commercial, industry, trains, planes, farms, forestry, hospital, fire stations, police, cemetery.....the list goes on. You can have numerous bus lines, color code each line and the actual bus color changes accordingly!! Fantastic attention to detail. More importantly its all done in a non-complicated and enjoyable experience.You can't change what a farm grows or how big each building is, you manage the overview of a complete city. The main focus is on building an efficient road system. It'll be very difficult to fail if you can do that, but being able to raise/lower roads you can build insanely complex road systems or be as simple as you like and build a quiet little town.A very well polished game, haven't encountered any bugs or crashes. Everything works as you'd expect it. A slow sense of achievement/attachment to your city as it grows. It's great to be able to zoom right in, hear the sounds of city life and just watch.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2015
												Cities: Skylines is a city builder developed by Colossal Order, the folks who were responsible for making the Cities in Motion series, and published by Paradox Interactive, and I have to say this is hands down the best city builder we’ve ever had on Steam .The scale of the game is simply astonishing, by default the game features a 36km2 map which is almost 10 times the size of the map you’re given in SimCity 2013, and with the help of mods from the Steam Workshop, this can be expanded to 100 km2, which is absolutely enormous. Even though there are no interactions between cities in different maps, it is frankly not necessary, with the help of the powerful yet easy to use building tool, you can simply build multiple cities on a single map.Despite the humongous size, the developers paid close attention to details, in fact, detail is the word I’ll use to describe this game. From the entire traffic network, down to individual citizens, every aspect in Cities: Skylines are properly simulated. You’ll find trucks, colour coded depending on what they are currently carrying, delivering their cargos to their designated factories, citizen actually live in a permanent home, and ambulances that will rush to the scene, then little paramedics will get out of the vehicle, and few seconds later return with a patient on a stretcher. I also love how water works in this game as well as the fluid physics, it is completely unnecessary to have it in a city builder but at the same time it adds so much to experience, water have currents and flows, and you'll want to pump water on the upstream and set up sewage pipes on the opposite side, else you’ll start pumping polluted sewage water back into the system. You can even completely drain a lake dry, or accidently flooding your city because you just demolished a dam, playing with water have never been so fun. This is a city builder perfected, further enriched by the endless creativity of the community with the support of Steam Workshop, and lastly accompanied by an unprecedented scale. Cities: Skylines is a must buy for anyone who has the slightest interest in city buildiers, especially with the affordable launch price.

content:
Posted: March 17, 2015
												This game is just fantastic in every aspect. You can just go ahead and buy it or you can read my experience with Cities: Skylines first if that is your fancy.Game is all around pretty great, satisfactory, balanced and it has a relaxed atmosphere. In this game there is no arsonists or disproportionate crime rate (I am looking at you SimCity!), everything is balanced maybe aside from everyone starting to die at the same time. You can just focus on building a very well designed city while keeping an eye on what your citizens need. Game itself is also constantly updated for balance or various fixes, and they release expansions in a true Paradox fashion by not making you feel like you have to buy it to access every feature on that DLC as they give you most substantial game mechanic updates for free with a patch, but of course for other optional features on that DLC, you are going to need to buy it. Now I will list some aspects of the game that I am enjoying the most;-Your space limitation basically depends on your hardware. For example, game allows you to have 9 tiles which are 2 square kilometers each and even a single tile is pretty big but if you so desire you can go beyond 9 tiles by using a mod to have all 25 tiles , however, if you do not own a powerful machine you will probably not be able to handle all 25 tiles that are filled with people and things.-Traffic. It is plain fun and pretty satisfactory to solve or at least alleviate traffic jams. I've been more focused on solving these problems than to collect garbage, dead people etc. Mainly because of that feeling of satisfaction after solving a traffic jam and seeing that intersection or interchange flowing... it fills me with pure joy just watching them. As I am writing this review I also am watching an interchange that has been flowing thanks to my awesome mayoring skills.-Mods and modding community. Since Colossal Order is not a huge company, naturally they could not fit every little detail they may have wanted to put in the game because they had to focus on more core elements of the game and this is where our lovely modding community comes in. You want limitless money? Sure. What about everything unlocked from the start? You got it! There are also hundreds of assets, maps and game mechanics in the Workshop. Basically, if you want something in the game that had not been put in by the devs themselves it probably exists in the Workshop or you can just make it yourself since asset editor is pretty easy to use as long as you are not planning to make something from ground up, because then you'd need some experience with that kind of stuff.-Colossal Order had said they will be going forward with Paradox model in terms of dlc. So basically, when they are going to put out a DLC, they will give some key features of that DLC for free like Paradox has been doing for their games (CK2, EU4). This is a huge plus in my book. And it also means that they are going to support this game for a very long time and they will not just release a new game every few years.-Paradox Interactive. These guys are the publisher of the game and unlike EA or Ubishit, they are not going suck us dry. I've been enjoying their games for almost a decade now and they have never disappointed me.-Public transport. You can set up your very own subway, bus and regular train stops that are actually helping with the traffic instead of clogging it (I'm looking at you SimCity!). You can set up as many routes as you'd like if you are into that kind of stuff. -Policies and districts. You can set districts. This allows you to create a specialized industry and/or to implement some interesting policies like only high tech buildings, heavy traffic ban, raise taxes for only that specific distirct etc... You can implement policies for the whole region too.- You can flood your city with poop water and watch those miserable scumbags suffer. I sometimes do that to a region just for fun. If I hear someone complaining about garbage not being collected I just plop a landfill on top of that whiny wimp's house. It fills me with joy, try it out.Warnings: If you like the genre I can assure you that you are going to be addicted to this game so beware. It can bring out the dictator in you. Your mind will see things differently when you are outside. For example; yestarday I took the bus for going back home and there was a serious traffic jam. I got up from my seat and started to analyse the road network around me to figure out what the problem is and how to solve it. I am a translator but after having played this game I'm thinking of picking up civil engineering it seems fun however in real life you can't just bulldoze something that is in your way which is unfortunate.To sum up, It is a fantastic game all around. If you like the genre and/or disappointed by latest SimCity and Cities XXL, I recommend picking this game up you'll love it. Price tag is also great. Considering they sold ShitCity for 60 dollars... I am pretty sure that I'm forgetting couple of things but alas, I have to go back and bulldoze houses of some whiny asshats. Anyways, thanks if you took the time to read my rather lenghty review. Also, Colossal Order, if you are reading this, THANK YOU! I give this game 1 GabeN (PRAISE HIM!) BUY THIS GAME IN THE NAME OF OUR HOLY SAVIOUR LORD GabeN!

content:
Posted: March 18, 2015
												Fantastic game, which was cheaper than SimCity 4.Each person, vehicle seems to be its own entity, but that is great for simulation.You need a good computer for this, it currently takes two cores and my graphics card seems to be running near the max speed. If you put the game into the fastest simulation speed, it takes up four cores. So, that has the hall mark of a well planned multicore support.The only downside I have is that is has the same commercial/offices to residential density problems that SimCIty 4 had. A few people living in apartments, but not enough jobs in buildings of similar size. The residential buildings have 70 people. All these big office buildings, including level 3 have less than 30 workers in them. I'm not sure that 1-2 person per floor (at the taller end) makes sense. This can be fixed with the multitude of mods though and there's enough to satisfy nearly everyone's wishes.Overall, an enjoyable game. Highly recommended.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												If you were in any way disappointed by SimCity, you should buy this game. The design shows a passion and love for what makes city-building games great, and the execution is near flawless. The road building tool is absolutely amazing. It is powerful enough to let you solve traffic issues logically, rather than figuring out work-arounds, or just suffering through traffic. That's not to say it's easy, it does constantly present thought provoking puzzles. But each issue with traffic has a HUGE number of solutions, and each one is fun to implement since the tool is so well designed. In fact, just designing interchanges is a blast.The new district feature is the best thing to come to city building games since map creation (also included btw). The control it gives you over your city allows you to build the city you want.The dynamic water adds some incredible life to the maps, which changes as your city grows and you make changes.City expansion makes planning much more complex and fluid than previous city building games. You will find that old strategies have to be rethought in a more realistic way.You can legalize drugs.There are a few bugs, but none are even close to game breaking. No need to wait for a patch, or servers. In it's current state it is the best city-sim I have ever played. I've only been able to play for a few hours so far, but I'm excited to get to the weekend and sink quite a few hours into this gem.9.5/10

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												This here is hands down the best city simulator on the market right now.Cities: Skylines takes the SimCity formula, builds upon it and then expands it even more, based upon Colossal Order's (the gamedevs) previous game development experience. If SimCity 2013 was too small for you and your people not having a permanent workplace and a home annoyed you immensely, then Cities: Skylines is what you need.Of course, some things that many people enjoyed in SimCity 2013, like modular buildings, are not present in this one, but this is only true for the out-of-the-box game. The wonderful thing about this game is that you have an enormously creative community that publishes a huge amount of mods that range from simple "quality of life" fixes to new game mechanics and total revamps. The game provides easy-to-use mod tools that allow you to stop relying on someone to make this thing you always wanted for you and try to create it yourself.All in all, this is is a great game that motivates you to learn new things (like real-world city and road design) and rewards you with stunning views of the masterpiece that you have built - only to encourage you to start a new city that would be even better and creative than the previous one.I have played this game for more than 100 hours and I definitely look forward to playing it more when the new Natural Disasters DLC comes out.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 22, 2015
												3/26/15: Fixed Spelling ErrorsCities: Skylines takes the faults in Sim City (2013), fixes them, adds its own style and begins our path to a long and fruitful franchise. It's the spiritual successor of Sim City (RIP Maxis). As the population of your city grows, the game unlocks buildings, monuments, new sources of power and city service buildings to help you craft your city. The best aspect of Skylines, took no more than a few days to take off- the modding community *slow clap*- you guys will continue to drive longevity and replay value by adding new content, imported buildings from past Sim City games, and mods to enhance our experience. Great work so far. Not to take anything away from Colossal Order. These guys fixed a lot of the bugs found in the first weekend in just 4 days. (keep in mind this is a team of 13!) This is the "Sim City" we've been waiting for. Could not be more happy.
