content:
Posted: February 13
												Now, I am going to take my time to write a review about this. Cities: Skylines is a city building game which I love. Simcity 2013 didn't satisfy me with the lack of realistic detail, mods and big maps like Cities: Skylines did. I have to hand it to Paradox for this game. You all met my satification with a game. The realistic feel to a big city, the amount of amazing detail put into this, THE MASSIVE WORKSHOP.. every little detail and it's still growing. I own nearly every DLC aside from the Natural Disasters DLC, both building addons and the Radio Station DLC due to some reasons. You're paying $17 for a DLC that yes, adds disasters and some more detail, but it still isn't worth $17. The two building DLC's that add new buildings are kind of pointless too considering you could go on the Steam Workshop and find/make your own. I found the Radio Station DLC pretty neat considering it takes away the plain old CSL Soundtrack but I just didn't bother buying it. I have over 100 hours (Yes it isn't a lot but I just made this account in the summer but I've been on this game for 2 years now) in Cities: Skylines and I still love playing it. I recommend this game with the following DLC's: After Dark and Snowfall. Those two DLC's added a lot and I really love them even though I barely use the snowfall maps haha. This game, be warned, is great but it's a pretty tough game to run at times. If you have a lot of items off the Steam Workshop like me, you'll be waiting at the loading screen for a good 5-7 minutes. I'm not complaining at all, but I'm just sending out a warning. I recently bought a new PC with good specs just to run this game. I run it on Very Good graphics at 60 fps while just starting my city/zoomed out but I hit around 25fps when I have a bigger city with around 40,000, lots of assets/props and A LOT of traffic. (This is on a GTX 1060 3gb btw)I do have some pros and cons about the game that I'll explain here:Pros:-Amazing Graphics/Detail  -Good Maps-Lots to do                         -Good AI -Massive Workshop           -Lots of cool DLC'sCons:-Harder game to run (Had to buy new $1300 PC)-Some rip-off DLC's-Traffic can be stupid at times hahaOverall, aside from my bad Pros & Cons list, I highly recommend this game for city builders. It's such a highly detailed game with amazing & fun things to do. 10/10 buy this game, totally worth it! :)

												Visual style might not be appealing to everyone (it seemed quickly-put-together at first), but UI itself is consistent and it's pretty easy to get around all the game's aspects which is a very important aspect for this genre.It is pretty easy to learn (only took me like 5 restarts from scratch lol) and has great creative potential. You will be able to manage transport, provide education and jobs, terraform your peace of land (or buy a new one, pretty cheap too) and build canals and many other things while the little bird at the top of the screen shows you how pleased your citizens are and if there are problems.The game also appears to support mods extensively which is bound to please us PCMasterricers.Pick it up along with 'After Dark' DLC (taxis and some other pretty-important stuff) and you will easily waste dozens of hours in this game without flinching if you are the slightest bit into that sort of thing.chirper/10

content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												If you were in any way disappointed by SimCity, you should buy this game. The design shows a passion and love for what makes city-building games great, and the execution is near flawless. The road building tool is absolutely amazing. It is powerful enough to let you solve traffic issues logically, rather than figuring out work-arounds, or just suffering through traffic. That's not to say it's easy, it does constantly present thought provoking puzzles. But each issue with traffic has a HUGE number of solutions, and each one is fun to implement since the tool is so well designed. In fact, just designing interchanges is a blast.The new district feature is the best thing to come to city building games since map creation (also included btw). The control it gives you over your city allows you to build the city you want.The dynamic water adds some incredible life to the maps, which changes as your city grows and you make changes.City expansion makes planning much more complex and fluid than previous city building games. You will find that old strategies have to be rethought in a more realistic way.You can legalize drugs.There are a few bugs, but none are even close to game breaking. No need to wait for a patch, or servers. In it's current state it is the best city-sim I have ever played. I've only been able to play for a few hours so far, but I'm excited to get to the weekend and sink quite a few hours into this gem.9.5/10

content:
Posted: March 24, 2015
												The city builder everyone has been waiting for since SC4 is here. Thank goodness.The original SimCity wasn't called a game by Will Wright, it's designer. It was called a software toy. That's because there was no winning or losing beyond some pretty basic functions (like not losing money) but was  a matter of how you wanted to create your city. How do you want your citizens to get to work? Do you want to create a city where most everyone walks through parks and forests? Do you want to create an ultra-dense metropolis? A suburban community? Now Maxis built on that formula and ultimately created the very complex and enjoyable SC4. It wasn't really a software toy any more though. It was a simulation.Skylines takes it back a bit towards the original SimCity. Whatever your dream is, you can pretty much create it in Skylines. This is the type of game where you can spend 30 minutes just building one intersection or do it in 5 second. You can spend hours crafting that new walking path or add 50,000 people to your city in that amount of time. They've added a host of options - road types, pathways, zones, policies which allow you to create most anything you can imagine. It's a ton of fun and harkens back to that Software Toy designation.Now it's not perfect. At times the game isn't challenging enough. You'll find yourself making tons of money and no real problems in your city (besides traffic). Traffic remains a stubborn problem sometimes no matter what you do. Since traffic impedes city services like fire, garbage and so forth it's not always an easy fix. But beyond that there's little challenge. In SC4 it was very easy to mess up the balance of a neighborhood and watch it crumble into decay. Skylines is much more forgiving and the lack of challenge is probably the biggest flaw.At the same time, you play a game like this simply create and have fun. You can create a small town or a massive metropolis. And unlike the Cities XL series, this one has personality. It's cool just following a vehicle around your city. The day/night cycle is interesting. I find the art style cute and the music charming. But what I like most of all is that you can really tailor the game to your goals and then drive forward towards those goals. And when you want to do something different, the game gives you the tools to pursue those new goals. I'm not just plopping down another generic neighborhood. I'm crafting a new development complete with walking trails around a pond. Or I'm crafting the majestic entrance off the freeway to my stunning metropolis. Or I'm crafing a self-sustainable logging community in the foothills, isolated away from the rest of the world. The choice is yours.The Steam Workshop integration helps too. You have many mods, buldings and other options to choose from and that kind of community involvement gave long legs to SC4. Thus Skylines is perfect for all ages and something that most gamers will greatly enjoy.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
Cities: Skylines ReviewIntroductionCities: Skylines is an utterly fantastic game. Paradox to this day has still never failed to deliver a great game. C:S as I will be calling it in this review is by far the greatest city-builder in it's genre. The realism of the game's details is striking and the way you handle your city's economics is not hard at all. Some people (like myself) will compare this to SimCity: Cities of Tomorrow, and at this point it's safe to assume the C:S has blown it out of the water. I'll put it here in bold: C:S is the better buy over SimCity: Cities of Tomorrow. The last EA game that I consider any good at all, was SimCity 4: Deluxe Edition. I've never throughoughly enjoyed a game that was produced by EA after that.Now C:S; yes, there are DLC's. Yes, they are paid for; but here's the beef on that. The base game is so good that the DLC's are out there to futher customize your city. And not cosmetically (essentially), I'm talking like, take for instance Match Day (which is the only free one at this point), it adds a Soccer stadium to the game. Yes it costs alot, yes it looks cool, and yes it actually does something. Your city must be able to handle the traffic flow of people coming in to see games in the stadium. The game events will cause massive influxes of money, but you have to be able to handle it. Point is, the DLC's in this game are useful (except maybe Snowfall, which has a heck a'lot of snow).General GameplayThe eccentricity of C:S compared to other games is incredible. Here I will discuss how and why it is. C:S offers many, many game mechanics that were never seen in previous city builders. One blatent example is the Steam Workshop. C:S has the ability for the community to create new content for the game and upload it so that others can incorporate it into their cities as well. Yes, SimCity 4 had assets (and dependencies, ahhhhhhhh dependencies), but you had to go through all the generic troubles of installing through directories and have the right dependencies (AHHHH). In C:S you check a box. Boom.C:S in-game mechanics include real-time water. I love this feature. I think it's one of the best mechnics in the game. SimCity 4 has water, but it doesnt...really....move. C:S does, and it moves! If you build a dam for hydroelectric energy, you better make sure that it was placed properly because (coming from personal experience) if you don't, and the water level behind the dam surges up and over the river banks and into your city and suddenly you lose half the populous of your city and then there's like no money, and a crap city, then oh well, you done did bad. That is what makes C:S so good. Your decisions make a direct impact on your society (not to say that you can direclty place this kind of house on this kind of zone (and correction, that is possible through assets in the Steam Workshop)).I don't think it's possible to right a review on this type of game without saying that there is quite a bit of a learning curve. C:S has a pretty big learning curve. Each city starts out with 2 highway connections. 1 incoming, and 1 outgoing. The way to plan this first part of your city will be your money maker. If you plan it badly, then your traffic will cause you some headache when you go to fix it and the placement of certain buildings like medical facilites and schools will make you lose money when you discover that they were placed in an area that won't let you upgrade a road, or something of that nature.Keeping on with the learning curve and moving into traffic. Traffic is another animal in this game. Yes, you have to worry about the flow of traffic in your city, becuase if your incoming traffic is being clogged up with trucks and what not becuase they are making this crazy turn in an intersection, it's safe to assume that you can change that into something more useful. The flow of traffic in your city needs to be carefully managed. Traffic is money. Outgoing goods from your industry earns your city money. So does incoming goods to commercial zones. You need to have an efficient route through your city if just passing through and so forth. C:S has spent a good amount of time developing this system and I have to admit, I'm still a little flumouxed on getting certain parts of my city to flow like they should.Last section in mechanics I want to talk about. Land Value. Ever since release, Paradox has added some amazing and cool looking things into the game. Canals for instance (yes, there are canals, and quays (keys), and other environmental tools) will provide a serious land value bonus to an area. The more desireable the city, the more people come, and the more people come, the more money you make. It's a very pleasing sight to see all that green in an area after you plop down a canal and the water is in there (not overflowing into your city as I have had before). The enviornmental set itself is a very intersting tab. Say you are designing a city not for the heck of playing the game, but because you want to design the most cool looking city you can (and you can, with the infinate money mode (screw the citizens!)), take "Strictoaster" on YouTube for example. He is a urban designer, that not only does it as his job, but in games such as C:S (his favorite) and Planet Coaster. His work is phenominal. It's a real testiment to the powerful game that C:S is.VisualsC:S is incredibly detailed. If you were to zoom in all the way onto a road, you could see the minute rocks and pieces of stuff that goes into making a road, IN THE ROAD. When it rains, there is flowing water on the sidewalks, and roads. Citizens will pull out their umbrellas and hats (some are caught off-guard and pull out a newspaper over the head). Not to mention the nighttime graphics. I think the best time a city is in the full screenshotting glory (unless you have a beefy computer (That is, better than this one I have)), is at night. The towering lights of skyscrapers, orange glows of the avenue street lights, and the sky-shining lights of suspension bridges over heavy waters. All of that is just incredibly well designed.I will have to throw this in there. C:S does require a bit of a good computer to get the game looking good. Playing it on a 1.4GHz i5 with integrated intel HD 5000 graphics doesn't do much for you (saying that from experience after looking at longer loading times, trees that look like pieces of plastic, and distance rendering that looks like blobs of paint on a box). I would suggest you actually read the system requirements to get the game running."Re-use" and Game LengthC:S is a city builder. The sheer amount of time you spend refining your city is enough to keep me realing on one map for weeks. C:S has an infinate amount of hours in it. Theoretically, as long as you don't get bored of it. As soon as you've spent that 3 month period on a city, and you have that feeling that you've done your best and it's done, you can simply start up a new one. On a new map. Or a community created one.Review OutlookMechanics: 8/10Visuals: 9/10Gameplay: 8/10Quality over SC:CoT: 10/10Overall: 9/10**Thanks for reading that, that's the longest review I've ever published. :P

content:
Posted: March 26, 2016
												Awesome city building game, reminded me of the Simcity 4 days. Bought this last december during the sale and only touched it this week, and it's a great game.Since there's too many things to say, I'll just say it in bullet formatTHE GOOD-Runs decent on my system, it can handle HUGE cities and has no problems whatsoever, it's about time we use that 64bit architecture. although I would say the performance could do a lot more better.-The city/traffic/civilian simulation is realistic. The cars and the people aren't just eyecandy, they actually do something. Everyone has a name, you can see where they live, see that they go to school/work, they buy their stuff and go to malls, etc. They could own a car or use public transport, you can actually follow them and see them do their daily affairs.-Traffic simulation is the best I've seen in ANY game. same with the civilians, there is an economy system and every car in the game has purpose, may it be delivering goods from industrial buildings to commercial buildings, or providing raw materials to industrial, or civilians going to school, work, garbage collectors, etc. -Public Transport is also the best, you can actually setup bus/train/metro lines or setup taxi services, ship lines and airlines, and see them in action and actually serving the civilians who are realistic as well as mentioned above.-The road placement is very flexible and allows you to build roads of all shapes and sizes, you can even adjust the height, up to the underground level. Because of this, Interchanges are in the game(and it's actually useful, because of realistic traffic simulation) and you can also make your own or get pre-made ones from the workshop.-♥♥♥♥ the grid system, you can design cities that have curvy roads, and it's as easy as doing grids, although I personally like doing grid system cities, a lot of people look for this specific feature-lastly, MODS, THOUSANDS OF MODS, are in the game, and If you've played Elder Scrolls, and Half-Life, you'd know how mods vastly improve the gameplay experience, this is one of those games where it's super mod friendly and allows for countless mods for various purposes to be made. Examples are pre-made road designs, new structures, cars, camera tweaks, maps, skins, even ones that make the game more realistic.THE BAD-the only bad thing for me is that it's hard to learn the basics, thankfully we have Steam Guides so I was able to learn the mechanics of the game quickly. Although I would say it's hard because it's that realistic, if you want a good road system you'd have to take a look at real life road systems. so you're not just learning the game mechanics, you're also learning how city traffic and roads work in real life as well.10/10 The best city building game I've played so far, ok the bullet format isn't much of a help, I still wrote a lot of things

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18, 2016
												If you want a great city building game, look no futher. It allows a high amount of professional and casual customization alike, with easy access and learning curve for the more indepth stuff for even those players like myself who were never really into the genre but had one or two titles we liked in the past 1-2 decades. Most of the (visual) content that's a paid expansion (night life, winter weather) are even included for free for everyone owning the base game, though more features (such as night and snow actually having effect on the city simulation and all the features related) are still of course included only in the DLC, you don't feel like you are missing out on anything if you don't buy them. In fact, it feels like you are getting great stuff for free, well integrated without "BUY THE DLC TO USE THIS" messages everywhere (dear EA, Ubisoft, and all you cashgrabs - this is how you make somebody WANT to support your projects).After SimCity2000 I came back to this genre with Topico 3 and I must honestly say that Cities: Skylines is really missing that personal touch Topico 3 had (and 4 lost, haven't played 5), so if you are looking for a mechanically friendly introduction to a complex simulation system, with a bit more "colder", professional feeling, Skylines is made for you. Plus it's usually super cheap for everyone like me who'd buy it as an experiment. You see, I don't have an outrageously high time spent with it, I had a single city that I grew bored of and left the game for likely forever, still I look back at it as a great game that was worth it's price on sale. If you are more dedicated to this genre than I am, you just cannot go wrong with Cities: Skylines.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2016
												i've only played a few city building/management simulator games, but i'm a fan of the genre. of the ones i've played, cities: skylines is by far the most indepth one i've come across. i almost didn't get it because i worried it would be too much for me to manage and that it would be more frustrating than fun, but i was happily wrong. i really enjoyed picking the right map and environment for the city i wanted to build. then having to make sure each zone had enough water and power while at the same time making sure the city was close, but not too close to the highway and train tracks. it took several attempts before i got a manageable city going. i forgot to put up fire and police departments one time. another time, i built right by the highway, but ended up backing up traffic for miles outside my city. yet another time i didn't set up garbage routes or crematoriums to dispose of the dead. there's so much going on in this game. once i figured out the different public transport systems and how to use them to lighten up traffic flow on the roads, and remembered all the different aspects of city management, i was able to get a good city going and raised it up to about 110K citizens before i moved on to another game. i haven't been back to this game in a while, but i plan on returning to tweak my city designs and expand. i want to unlock and build more of the monuments as well as try out the different DLCs for this game. i picked up the snowfall dlc, but haven't exploed it much beyond using the trams and setting up tram lines in my towns. i want to get and try out the after dark dlc soon too. perhaps i'll updaye my review around then as well

content:
Posted: May 22, 2015
												Let's be honest, you are reading reviews because you want reassurance that its a good game.I'll keep it short. Sim City sucked, this doesn't. Collossal Order is still developing DLC for the game with the intent of making the main mechanics free downloads and the paid DLC big extensions. There are tons of mods available (and I mean tons) to plug the gaps that CO left for us to build on (nice way of saying missed).The maps are huge, this is the way Sim City should have been. If you even have a slight leaning towards city simulation games, stop thinking, reward yourself and buy this game.Besides CO are Finnish, and Finnish are nice humble people, and boy do they know their subject matter. Its nice to know that there are ethical developers out there still and I like to reward developers like that who make a game the way gamers want it.UPDATE: While the DLC has been rather ho hum, with such great mods, you can't half blame the developers if they have difficulty finding new things to add. That said, I think they have plenty of space to go, such as being able to edit lanes on a road? Huh CO? Please?BTW the game is still excellent. Still pouring hours into this thing, especially with the awesome new mods that come out everyday.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												Wow, Cities: Skylines... Where to begin...- Firstly, this game is the game that EA's Simcity should have been, except about 1000 times better. More buildings, more options, better gameplay mechanics and generally more everything!- Secondly, The gameplay and the customisation feature of this game are truely its strong point. With thousands of Workshop items, assets and vechicles created by a community of dedicated fans that are added to your game with a simple click. This adds a whole new level to a game which no other rival city builder can truely compare to. Did I mention that these Workshop add-ons are FREE???- Thirdly, The Developers ACTUALLY CARE ABOUT THE GAME. That is one thing that EA missed on with Simcity, EA just rode the current of their popularity river that the Sim series has created and as soon as the game was released, the game was mostly left to cough, splutter and die due to its lack of new features, AI problems and repetitiveness. Simcity did see a few updates but nothing compared to the love this game has recieved from the developers.This game has problems though, it has to be said. I have experienced problems during my play time, mainly around the stability on my PC, especially seeing as I am not running your typical /r/pcmasterrace beast machine. Asides from the occational lapse of framerate, crashes can occur. In the past, I have been left with a few hours of progress wiped because of foolishly not saving my progress. Collosial Order seem to have fixed this as crashes seem to happen less frequently then it used to but I do still see a occasional drop of FPS in my game, but again, I am not running an epic PC. Thinking of it, this game is so addicting that I have had to force myself to save or enable autosave.But that's really it, a lot of pros and a few tiny cons. Cities: Skylines is a must have for gamers who like Simulation games, City Builders, Moddable games and a whole lot of mircomanaging.EDIT (25/11/'16): I highly recommend buying the game with the extra DLCs. Although it will set you back a bit more, you will be supporting future development of the game and the extra features are mostly worth it. Think of it as a virtual highfive to the devs.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2015
												This doesn't just hit a home run, Cities SKYLINES bats it out of the park into orbit and to the moon Alice... and then some.9 Hours into this game and I just can't put it down.  NO LAG, NONE, ZIP, ZERO, this game runs SMOOTH (specs below).Started my first city today, messed about for 5-15 minutes getting the feel, then threw that away to start fresh now knowing what I need to do.  Having been playing 'Simcity' since the SNES version was released around 92 or so...Built roads, facilities, zoned as needed.  Plenty of options.  You purchase more map tiles as you go, they are part of your live city.  No loading/saving to access another tile.  This game is downright awesome with that expansion bit - they nailed it.  I mean NAILED IT.  This is the TRUE SUCCESSOR TO SIMCITY 4 DELUXE.  THIS IS WHAT SC2013 SHOULD HAVE BEEN.  I'll write this again so everyone can see it. THIS IS THE TRUE SUCCESSOR TO SIMCITY 4 DELUXE, THIS IS WHAT SIMCITY 2013 SHOULD HAVE BEEN.  IF YOU LOVED SIMCITY 4 AND PLAY IT TO THIS DAY, BUY THIS.  ENTIRELY WORTH IT, VERY AFFORDABLE!  There was Simcity on the SNES and pc.  Then there was Simcity 2000 on DOS 6.x on the venerable amd 486 66 ...Then there was Simcity 3000... but 2000 and 3000 didn't quite capture the magic that Nintendo put into the SNES version.  For so many years I kept that SNES and Simcity... and then Simcity 4 came out... it was good, but not until Rush Hour expansion was it great.  Rush Hour combined into the Original was also marketed as the Deluxe version.  Adding in the NAM mod to Simcity 4 deluxe made the game really awesome if you were into highway design, and really could excell at traffic management.  Cities XL was buggy, and laggy... and very vague (and therefor frustrating).  Cities XXL had promise but just did not deliver beyond multicore enhancements - it was generally everything (bad with the good) that XL was... re-wrapped into a new package.  Simcity 2013 had promise, but EA's greedyness and needless DRM and small city sizes/day 1 bugs really got the game off to a bad start.  You just couldn't build to your imagination's content like you could in Simcity 4 Deluxe - beyond the initial degridding.  Simcity 2013 was like a demo, a demo of something that could have been so awesome...  but last week... last week I heard some bad news.Maxis, to us City-Building afficianados - was something quite dear - Maxis was shuttered.  The Sims (EU studio) live on, but Simcity, as we know it, was official pulled off life support and pronounced dead... and know I know why.This game.  GOD BLESS THESE DEVS, SKYLINES NAILS IT.  EVERYTHING.  5/5!!!There is SO much realism packed into this game, and many things I did not expect.Traffic management? Check!Ability to build with realism using roads/avenues/bypasses to hearts content? Check!Highways, offramps/onramps buildable?  Check!Multilevel bridge over bridge stuffs for super-snazzy interchanges?  Check! (Roundabout, cloverloaf, diamond, trumpet, freeform entirely -not just PREFABS only, if you like - your imagination and the space available is your only limit)Large expansion of the city as needed?  Check! (more with MOD support)64bit exe and NO memory leaks?  Check!GREAT graphics (for a city builder)?  Check!  [Directx 11 video card required under Windows!]Sufficient sound feedback and decent music?  Check!  (Music in non-intrusive, sound fx I have no complaints on)Good play control/movement/UI design?  Check!Mod support?  Well, not yet - but devs are promising it!Healthcare AND deathcare? EEK!  Check!Trains for passengers AND freight?  Check! Seaports for passengers AND freight?  Check!  (improves industrial demand)Airports to attract more tourists and connect you better to the outside world (and their money!!!)? Check!Ability to creat custom maps and a terrain editor (and importing greyscale heightmaps)? Check!Ability to build in sunny tropical climate, or the more northern latitudes (custom gfx, sun angle)? Check!Broad range of options to customize the game to your hardwares ability/disability?  Check!Alternative ways to solve the many problems you face, and the ability to see you have them? Check & double Check!!!Game breaking bugs?  Nope - not in over 9 hours into it... not anything I can see. No CTDs, no glitchyness, nothing.I could go on and on...  58,000+ people in the city, 6 million in the treasury and making a good income monthly.I just can't seem to want to stop playing or get bored of this... I am absolutely in shock at how good this game is. Simcity 4 Diehards, This is the game WE have been waiting for - do NOT hesitate!  NO REGRETS HERE!THIS GAME IS NOT AND IS NOT AFFILIATED WITH CITIES XL OR CITIES XXL IN ANY WAY/SHAPE/FORM, OTHER THAN IT BEING A CITY BUILDER, A GOOD ONE AT THAT, A REALLY REALLY GOOD ONE. There are only TWO reasons you should not buy this game. 1.) If you cannot afford it.  The price IS very reasonable - VERY REASONABLE.2.) If you have a video card that is not capable of DirectX 11.  Do not use Intel video, it's glitchy.That said, those on Intel-based laptops, you need to force this game to use the dedicated AMD or NVIDIA gpu, otherwise it will be slow and glitchy defaulting to the laptop's Intel gfx.  You can do this from inside AMD Catylist, or Nvidia Control Panel.  You can find these solutions in the discussion forums here on Steam.  INTEL GFX IS NOT SUPPORTED.As stated above, hardware specs are here:i7 4790k @ 4.6ghz on Asus Maximus Hero VII Z97 Chipset motherboard16gb 2400mhz ram (8gb x2) corsair dominatorAsus Radeon 7850 2gb gddr5 [1ghz core] video card with Direct CU II cooling (the don't-ever-hear-it cooler)Dual Toshiba SSD drives in Raid 0 for OS & Games, for quick loading (almost zero load times. maybe a second or two)Soundblaster X-fi Titanium pro soundcardFractal Arc XL case with Seasonic 750 watt PSU, and Phanteks somethin'-14 red coolerI listed everything in the event someone wants to dupe the whole hardware config, game runs AWESOME.  NO LAG on HIGH settings.Seriously, get this game now.  You'll be glad you did.   The devs really got this one right.  Finally, A SIMCITY 4 REPLACEMENT!If you're a small kid with no money, do some extra chores for money!  Paint the dog, wash the lawn, mow the hedges, trim the carpet, vacuum the dishes, sweep the walls, scrub the garden, tiedye your white kittycat, ANYTHING to make money to buy this game (actually forget the bit with the cat, that might get you grounded, or worse, clawed and grounded).Can't wait to see what the NAM team does with this one :)--Cheers guys and good luck!  ... now if I can just kill that annoying little blue bird...***Laptop users DON'T forget if you have intel GFX to make sure this game uses the AMD or NVIDIA GPU!  Desktop users should be just dandy as this issue won't happen.  AGAIN, INTEL GFX IS NOT SUPPORTED AT THIS TIME/POSSIBLY EVER.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2015
												About time we have a good City Builder from a reputed company.After playing this for some time, here are some feedback compared to SimCity4: Deluxe.PRO:1. Game starts as expected. Build some roads, electric, water, and zones.  Bulldozing gives money back instead of costing money.You don't spend money to zone or re-zone.  You can easily lose if you screw up this part. A second failure point that can crop up at this stage is placing something now that creates a pollution hub later.2. There is a lot to manage but you start small - then as you get bigger, the more you need to manage. Progression feels good and appropriate for a game in this genre. Pacing is also smooth. The Pace is dictated by Milestones, as you reach certain goals in the game you get to purchase more land, unlock buildings and more upgrades.3.  Mods in this game are pretty good in their potential.  Anyone can make Assets or Maps.  4. There is enough to simulate to entertain you but there isn't too much depth.  The level of depth feels appropriate.  Not dumbed down by any means.5. Lots of potential room for DLC, Expansions and more content WITHOUT being stripped down to nothing.  This is not a half-game awaiting the rest in microtransactions. CON: No big flaws yet.  1. Some parts of the UI are primitive.  When you click to view Energy, Waste, Fire or Crime, it doesn't tell you how much money you are spending on it. So there is some juggling of one tab to the next.2. You cannot move or re-size the windows that open for you when you click buttons.3. The music could have a better presence.  It is a bit quiet and often I hear nothing but birds.4. "Forced" to start small and build big from scratch.  You "can cheat" if you like, but playing without cheats you cannot just start building a large city. Some people might dislike having the same starting situation evey single time on terms of what you can build and how you advance.Linear Progression is the rule of this Sandbox.  Fortunately, you can advance in a non-linear way. Overall:  9/10.  The only thing that could have made this game better is to have more control over the size of Zones - the "Zones" appear next to road types when you build roads. You don't place "zones." Once the road is placed and the "Zone Spot" appears next to the road, you may designate that as Residential, Commercial or Industial.This is the best City Builder on the market, period.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2015
												Day One review:GET IT... it's awesome, does have a few glitches, but they will be worked out....DAY TWO UPDATE:Well I'm 18 hours in... I have noticed a few hiccups, I have 2 pc's, one @ Work one @ Home, The work pc is technically slower than my home pc, but loads Skylines quicker. Don't ask why IDK... Also, I was one of those people who subscribed to mods before release, bad move.. Most got duplicated instead of updated, and my game went bonkers, I had to remove each mod in game, which for some reason is a chore, you can only delete one at a time.. Also, gameplay, The core game is weird, and I hung around long enough to get a few acheivements, but I've switched over to Sandbox mode, why? because the finance model is flawed, I can have 10% tax on everyone and still lose money..  I will just play with unlimited funds & a few good unlimited resource mods.. The map editor could use a video tutorial, I have played games with map editors before, but for some reason this editor just doesn't feel as good as it could...So, definitely get this game it is better than SIMCITY & Cities XXL series.. just don't think it's all peaches & creme.. there are some head scratching moments... But CO is good about support for their games...Day 2 update part two:28 Hours in, I have ditched the base game mode for now, the MODS & Sandbox definitely save this game, I have built a city w/ 100,000 people in it, but still somehow, industry didn't have enough people to fill the jobs... REALLY? Also, building up for the monuments is pretty difficult if not somewhat impossible without mods.. I have unlocked 25 city tiles, and have laid out seperate districts, so in a sense, from some screenshots i posted it looks like a free form region builder, instead of the constrained regions of SIMCITY 2013.. I would be able to fill in all the gaps, but That could take a few more days, besides that, a full 2x2km section in my city is all railroads & highways.. I honestly can't see myself going back to no mods, not until some stupid routing bugs get squashed.. Why have 3-6 lane highways? The CIMS only use 1 freaking lane... But other than that, this game does beats the tar out of Simcity as a whole.. I can't see myself ever going back to SIMCITY 4 or 2013.. Skylines has definitely won me over... I am patiently awaiting TUNNELS & major bug fixes..

content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
												Refreshing city building game that touches on the roots of the original Sim City games. As a complete package I would rate this game over Sim City and it's expansion pack "Cities of Tomorrow". Bigger zones to build out on, basically these equal the size of Sim City regions. Better road management options, better public transport option (subways!), Day/Night cycle based budgeting, mods, great graphics, overall a more complicated but more rewarding game.Couple of things it falls short on would be budgeting, while you have more fine tuned options to adjust your finances, it lacks the ability that Sim City has where you can indivualy reduce/increase funding to say schools. In Cities Skylines if you adjust the budget for Education it affects all schools, so for example one school may need more funding because it overcrowed. By increasing the funding to education it increases all school funding nore matter the type. So while I may now have enough money to suuport the Elementary school, my high school is now over funded. Region play is missing from Cities: Skyline but makes up for it in the size of maps. Plus the avaliability of terraforming and making your own map!Industry is handled better in Sim City than Cities: Skylines hands down. While in Sim City specializing in certain industries (Oil, Ore, etc..) has a progression type mechanic too it, you dont start out with all the goodies. In Skylines you more or less lay down Industry tiles, district it to whatever you're trying to produce (farms for instance) and just kind of let it go. No real interaction with it like there is with Industry in Sim City.In my personal opinion it's still a vastly more fun game and with Steam Workshop support the possiblities are endless!

content:
Posted: March 18, 2015
												It's been a long time since a really good City Builder has been on the market so every time there is a whisper of a new one being developed, fans of the genre like myself become eager with anticipation. Unfortunately, we have been left wanting for nearly a decade. Yes, it's been that long since a really decent sim has been released. Upon learning that one of my favorite publishers, Paradox Interactive, had a City Building simulation in the works I knew this was a game I could not wait to get my hands on. Paradox Interactive is known for being a leader in challenging and entertaining strategic games so I felt if anybody could do it right, they could. Having been able to test the game for almost a full week before its official release I can say that my trust was not misplaced. Cities Skylines is everything I hoped it would be. This is city building done right.I have played most every City Building game ever made and consider myself somewhat of an expert in the genre. Perhaps I am over-critical at times when it comes to my favorite gaming genre but it comes from the desire to find the Holy Grail in city sims. I can honestly say, Cities Skylines is far and above, the best city building simulation ever made. Period. Colossal Order has come up with a recipe that ingenuously combines just the right amount of simplistic game design with a flavorful amount of challenging gameplay to create a masterpiece. Fans of City Building simulations will definitely not want to miss grabbing this game.There is a very realistic feel to this game. It's not just about throwing out color-coded building zones, but more about true city management. Do things right and your populus will be greatful and steadily grow. Do things poorly and your city will clear out faster than a zombie apocalypse could make it happen. Numerous tools are at your disposal as expected with an interesting dynamic that truly brings the realism into the game. Cities can be carved up into different districts and each district can have its own set of policies and characteristics. Players even choose the names. But it doesn't just stop there. Players can give custom names to just about everything in the game including its citizens. Transportation and pollution will be key challenges as with any game of this type. Having experience with previous endeavors like the Cities in Motion series, Colossal Order has easily found a way to challenge players along these lines. Cars and trains, ships and planes. Cities Skylines has it all. The water simulation is spectacular as well. Placing your sewage disposal upstream, for example, could result in contaminating your citizens' water supply. Realistic flooding is another possible scenario. The maps included are gigantic and beautifully designed terrains that offer endless possibilites when planning your city and continued population growth unlocks the ability to expand to adjacent tiles on the map as well as making more buildings and options available (such as taking out loans). These options are tied in with overall success and not just simply from having enough funds available, a feature which definitely enhances the experience.I could go on and on about all of the things I admire about this game. The graphics are solid but not overly done which allows for most systems to be able to run this game smoothly. The UI is easy to use and understand. The "Chirper" social media feature is a clever modern touch that keeps mayors abreast of public opinion and concerns. And, perhaps one of this game's best features is the inclusion of asset and map editting tools to allow the Steam Community to heavily mod this game in order to continue its growth and stability in the future while adding tons of extra content and replay value. In fact, about the only area I found lacking in this game is not having a variety of random events such as natural disasters. I cannot say with certainty why the developers chose not to include them and perhaps they will be added later as DLC since most Paradox Interactive games are known to offer quality additional content long after initial releases. The modding community could possibly offer them as well, since I predict the Steam Workshop will quickly fill up with a large variety of added content. Fires, floods, pollution, infrastructure and transportation issues are still more than enough to keep players challenged and fully engaged though, so overall its not really a major concern.The Good:+ Solid graphics and rich detail.+ Realistic simulation elements.+ Challenging gameplay with various difficulty settings.+ Variety of buildings.+ Many customization options.+ Easy-to-use UI.+ Extremely high replay value.+ Mod-friendly with editting tools included.+ Steam Trading Cards & Achievements.+ Pleasant audio/background music.The Bad:+ Lack of random events/natural disasters.+ Graphics could be more life-like.+ Terrain cannot be changed during actual gameplay.Final Thoughts:Cities Skylines is the best City Building simulation developed in a long time and quite possibly the best ever. Expect this game to continue to grow in popularity and become the new industry standard for games of this type. An amazing game with well-designed features integrated into it for such a small development team and a limited budget. Its definitely worth the price and I highly recommend this game to all fans of simulated strategy/cty building games.

number of helpful: 20 of 38 people (53%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 25, 2016
												I've played 10 hours and I have seen everything the game has to offer.There's next to no challenge is this game, once you get your city of the ground. After that, it is chugging out more zones for the city to grow.People complaining about not enough healthcare? Dump another hospital somewhere in the vicinity and the issue is solved. Once your city is going money is no longer an issue.This cycle repeats until you are too bored to continue.The only interesting and difficult part is managing your traffic, which is somewhat annoying since you need to reach a certain population milestone before you can start building highways and such, making it hard to plan your infrastructure in advance.There's also this amazing feature of the game (or maybe Unity) eating up as much RAM it can get its hands on. My system has 6GB of RAM and Cities: Skylines decided it should use 4GB of that storing god knows what. Chrome even had to move all of my tabs to the pagefile to make room for the game.This game is fun, but only for a short bit. Don't pay much more than a tenner for this game.

number of helpful: 49 of 96 people (51%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 1, 2016
												This game is advertised as a 'challenging simulation' so I bought it with expectations to get a city planner/builder with depth, challenge and realism. All I got was a shallow sandbox game. You can spice up the difficulty with a hard mode and mods, which basically results in having less money and income thus having to wait longer to be able to buy the stuff needed to progress.Yet there is nothing that can make up for the lack of more complex game mechanics. The game offers an over the top local traffic simulation which is far from believable and some minor challenges which are easily overcome by building appropriate infrastructure at the right spots.There are indeed a few mechanics where policies and economy matter, but nothing to write home about. In general the game feels incomplete and oversimplified.+ If you like sandbox games with good mod support and simply enjoy building beautiful cities you will probably also like this. - If you're a fan of simulations and believable game worlds you will be highly disappointed. Not worth your time and money. Gets boring quickly and lacks replay value.

number of helpful: 60 of 117 people (51%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 27, 2015
												This game is good as a City builder sandbox. But will fail to captivate Simcity 4 fans. Why?Because he management part is simple! There is no real challenge to the game thanks to a progression system and the inability to experiment.All these flaws rears it's head 5 hours into the game. Visual and performance-wise it's fine, nothing to really complain about, the workshop would solve the generic art direction. There are few good ideas here and there,  like how far a service can be reached is shown by street instead of the usual circle. There are some other good ideas which seem incomplete or not having a prominent, noticable effect - e.g.: Day and Night budgets.But the game focuses on macro-management rather than micromanagement. Pro: it's less overwhelming for those looking for a sandbox experience.Con : it's too limited for challenges in maintaining a city.  Examples would be how taxation is done, how zones are handled, how structures are available.  All of these have a formula to them, without anything disrupting the formula. The game overall becomes a formula.  No Natural disasters. Fires are harmless and only burns down the building without spreading. The problem solving? Formula!Decision has a consequence, consequence has a solution, 99% it ends there No rinse repeat. Therefore the game just doesn't throw challenges.The progression system is the big deal breaker here. It allows you to play safe without experimentation. In order to get buildings you need to cross a certain amount of population. In my first city I happened to unlock buildings conveniently as I could afford them and sustain them. For some reason it's easy to  earn more money than you spend. There is alot of bad UI decisions, one notable one - the annoying twitter bird, that sits inconvieniently on top-center of the screen. The game is also missing a way to control day and night cycle, however I realized that that would break the game budget mechanic (which allows you to set budget for services based on time - Again a good idea which is very underdeveloped).It's here when the mirror begins to crack. The games popularity and critical acclaim comes from all the anger and spite towards EA's Simcity 5, which I though was such an awful game that people consider mediocre titles like "Cities Skylines" as the resurrection of the city building genre which we've been desiring since Cities XL. Yes, that game we would be playing if it wasn't for the crappy engine. Bottom-line, C:S is good as a sandbox for your young one or casual relaxing city building experience. It's bench-marked with SImcity 5, a game which can make a - square drawn in MS paint and exported as a jpeg then renamed to a .exe - look better.Planning takes a backseat here, sadly that part was never advertised. Because this was always advertised as "A deserved sequel to Simcity 4". This game seems unfinished and the gameplay is very underdeveloped.

number of helpful: 24 of 46 people (52%) found this review helpful98 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 22, 2016
												You can stalk your own citizens! I followed a guy named Mark (I forgot his last name). I was for sure Mark was a terrorist. He looked like a terrorist, smelled like a terrorist, and even talked like a terrorist, or so I imagined. He had just gotten off of his boat as a tourist.All his other tourist friends took the subway, but not Mark. Mark took his car... Fishy right? I followed him in his green van. I knew something was up. Who drives a green van? Mark does. He got onto my freeway and this is where I knew it would go down. Traffic was backed up for miles. What did Mark do? He waited, just sat there. His plan was failing, and I knew it. All of the sudden he merged into the left lane. Oh no! His plan was back into action.He later turned into my industrial area. Well played Mark, you though I would be stupid enough to think you worked in industry. Well guess what MARK! I know you were a tourist! You don't work in MY city! He couldn't shake me, and he knew it.He continued on with his plans to terrorize my city! There he drove back onto the freeway. Trying to cover his tracks I see... He merged left. Then left again. He turned... right into my tourist area. How suspicious I thought. He only wanted me to think that he was a tourist in my city. I wouldn't fall for it. He parked his green van on the right side of my road, only this road was no parking! Mark had slipped up. I knew he was up to something as he got out and went to go "sight see." I would NOT fall for that Mark. Not this time.Hours passed, days it seemed, and yet he was still sight seeing in my tourist district. I had to think of something before he carried on with his plan. It was too late. Mark got back into his car... I knew this would be it as he turned on his blinker politely and merged back onto my freeway. He was going to blow up my bridge... I saw it in his eyes, eyes that deceived everyone. Those crystal blue eyes hid a dark secret that I had yet to find out.The sweat ran down my face as Mark crossed my bridge. It was safe. But he was heading back to the tourist ships, there he would surely make his move. He didn't... He left my city. Until we meet again Mark. I'm onto you.9/11 ......Mark

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6
												Citites: Skylines is both more forgiving and more in-depth than the likes of SimCity 4. Running out of money is a lot tougher, and there's a lot more to manage like the size of your roads, sewage, and cemetaries. The game starts off really slow as, unline in SimCity where unlocks are based on the year, the unlocks here are based on population, so you start off with coal power and no high-density zoning. Over time, the game opens up, and you get a lot of room to build and experiment. If you like city builders, this game is definitely a solid 9/10, it shines in comparison to the likes of the newer and even the classic SimCities.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2015
This is truly, an amzing game.As a SimCity player, I found this to be astronomically better than SimCity 5 and topping SimCity 4.First of all, it doesn't force anything to you. You can do whatever you want; create small/big cities, have education or not, even to having parks or not. This game leaves it all to the player to decide.With the addition of Steam Workshop support, you can add different building/vehicle models, as well as having a new Traffic mechanism (with Traffic++), and having the freedom to unlock all 25 tiles.This game will last for decades, just as SimCity 4 did it. It will be fun to play it every years to come, as new expansions come out and as the game evolves to be that one perfect city simulator.There is only one thing that I have a problem with. No, it's not Chirpy, not the stupid "Have you tried this building yet?" when I get new assets, no. It's that it doesn't have multiplayer. That is the only thing that I miss from SimCity 5. I don't have the option to play with my friends.If that is no problem for you (as it isn't a big of a problem for me), then you should definitely get this game. I totally recommend it.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2015
												See my hours played... 'nuff said.  It still has some UI challenges (counterintuitive/uninformational info screens), but this is a solid must-buy for city builder fans.The developer is a small team, yet still responsive to the player base when bugs ARE found.UPDATE: Adding this three months later. I am still happily playing this thing! The After Dark add-on is my next purchase. For those considering it, if all you want is day-night cycles, you get that for free from the developer. Most of the previous annoying true bugs and limitations (world holes, low polygon limit, drivers lining up in one lane) have been patched now. I want to buy the DLC for the added commercial district specialization (not too excited about prisons, as crime management is not that difficult).Note on the drivers only using one lane: if you're still getting this, it's your road design,not the game. See the citiesskylines reddit for how to fix your roads to prevent it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2015
												This is my first review I've written, so here it goes.I've played Cities Skylines for 350+ hours so far, including the After Dark DLC, and I can truly say that I am addicted to this game. Ever since it came out on March 10th, I barely have time to play any other game that I've bought because I just can't get enough of it. I downloaded Steam primarily to play this game after playing SimCity 2013 for two years prior.I can honestly say that this game makes up for the mistakes SimCity 2013 made. Cities Skylines contains bigger cities, cims have a home and job which they actually travel to (instead of randomly parking at the nearest home or building), creating your own maps in the map editor, and workshop support which modders have posted some outstanding work on. I could list even more pros but I would be rambling on forever. The other thing I like is that the devs at Colossal Order are actually listening to the community, replying to users questions and concerns, and are working their absolute hardest to satisfy everyone, and if they can't do something, the modders are always willing to give it a try.Now the game is not perfect. It can get laggy (at least for me) sometimes but that's really minor and I can deal with that. I'd like to see some weather changes added to the game but I am in no hurry to see huge updates as the game has surpassed my expectations. I'd like to have the population limit of 1 million increased although, I completely understand why the devs put it in. Although, I thought I saw that in the last update that several limitations were increased, though I can't be sure if the population limit has changed. Other than that, I have no real complaints or concerns at this point and I fully recommend Cities Skylines. If I had to give it a rating, I'd give it 9 out of 10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 20, 2015
												Cities: Skylines by itself is enjoyable city management simulation that I have ever played in all the years of city simulation games.Though starting area is small, you could eventually expand to a vast area that you can you can build a different area on the same map like a different town. You can assign policies to specific districts, or the whole city, where you can specify things like free transport, or higher/lower tax just for a district for a specific industry.I have played enough to encounter traffic congestion where finding the source requires careful attention to what caused it. It can be as simple as having too many intersections close together, to as complicated as to how to direct the massively long traffic headed specifically to the cargo ports that weren't somehow using the train freight depot you placed right next to it. Sometimes you find out that using 2 lanes instead of 6 lanes for one-way roundabouts results in smoother traffic. It's something not immediately obvious that you need to think about to solve it. The post-release update that allows tracks and roads to go underground makes building through hills and crowded districts easier.Just as if that is not enough, there are additional content in the Steam Workshop that makes managing things like public transport easier, or you could even create your own assets and maps from within the game itself to publish to the workshop.If you like managing or building cities, this is the game for you!24 November 2016 edit:While After Dark DLC adds day/night cycle, you don't actually need to buy the DLC to experience it. What you do get with it are jails to move criminals away from crowded police stations, massive bus stations (handy for me as I build multiple lines through a busy downtown), taxis for tourists to get around plus deports for the taxis to spawn from. Dedicated bus helps keep your citizens from blocking your buses and taxis. Bicycle lanes too to help your people get around faster, but without the problems of a car. And finally, Leisure and Entertainment districts (you can set them like how you set up different industries). Paid aspect of the DLC isn't really game-changing, but I did it to support the developers.Snowfall DLC – This adds snow-covered maps, plopable buildings unique to it, as well as trams! You don't need to create a new snow map just for trams: it will work with your existing maps along with other utility related features. Heating adds additional difficulty in managing your map, and is somewhat mandatory for snow maps as, if you do nothing about it: surge in temperatures can cause issues for your power supply as electrical heating is the only way for people to keep warm. To bring more efficient heating, just build a heating plant and upgrade your existing pipes for water and sewage. People may not like how the snow is eternal, or not able to convert an existing city, but as someone who rarely ever experience a snow-covered city, I find it quite fun.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6
												Better than SimCity. Get it.I'll eventually spend the time to write a massive, helpful, and unbiased review, but I want to put at least 75-100 hours into the game and do just about everything first.For now though, I leave you with this:-Traffic is pretty good, there's mods that will make it amazing-Zones are great, there's a mod that makes them even better-Customization is excellent-You don't need to make multiple neighboring cities for your economy to work unlike earlier SimCity games-Adding public transport such as busses and subways actually decreases traffic realistically-Mods actually work and are easy to get-Balancing the budget isn't too difficult after the first city or two, meaning the game becomes a relaxing simulator after a few attempts when you know how to make a proper city.The only complaints I have are:-Need more tutorials or even tutorial maps, please. Not a big deal, just that it took me 50 hours to learn how to 100% properly manage traffic.-Schools in high density residential zones fill up super fast, would have been nice to have larger capacity schools.-Traffic can be a bit overexaggerated sometimes, but mods will help you make traffic better.-Taxes only impact growth and happiness if they're too high (which reduces happiness and growth.), would have been nicer if having low taxes made the city grow faster and more businesses and industry pop up.-The DLCs aren't worth the money (except maybe Snowfall), they just don't add enough, would be better if they were only $5 DLCs or came with the game. Not a huge complaint though.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2015
												Cities: Skylines does a great job of taking the fundamental ideas that Sim City 4 attempted and addressing every issue that the community had with it. The resulting game is something that has the same look and feel of its elder genre brethren but has many of the features the community wanted in it. That doesn't necessarily make it the game that Sim City should aspire to be, indeed Skylines lacks any real originality or direction to where it might be going in the future. It's a solid title, one that plays a heck of a lot better than Sim City 4 did, however it's derivative and the onus is on the community to take it in new and strange directions to help differentiate it from its main competitor. That being said it's still enjoyable to play and most certainly worth its current asking price.Read my full review here: http://www.therefinedgeek.com.au/index.php/2015/03/20/cities-skylines-i-am-a-generous-mayor/

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
												Cities: Skylines is what the latest Sim City should have been.  A complete city simulation but be warned of the expansions as they do not yeild enough content to warrant the price!   Cities: Skylines in a brief description is a city simulation in which your ultimate goal is to design a city that meets your requirements.  There is no actual objective, no missions, just a pure sandbox play.  You start with a tiny town and slowly grow into a spawling city.  As you level up your city through population milestones you unlock more necessities of a large city.  Proper planning goes a long way when it comes to city and even town design.  You can quickly have a large traffic jam for miles if you don't engineer your roads correctly.  Even if you create a 6 lane highway to bypass traffic, the rules in this game will insist the that inhabitants of the area take the shortest route not the quickest route.  This must be considered when designing the road systems from the very beginning.  It is all too easy to get caught up in building out blocks and areas for your industry and commerce and totally forget about the road requirements.  An easy way to start off is to build a road then delete it, this opens up other roads that are not initally available for some reason.  As you progress you can make freeways, underground roads and suspended roads for more efficient travel.  It takes a civil engineer to make a good road system and I obviously need much to learn in this department despite my advances in understanding how to properly build a road system.  As you grow you zone your areas much like Sim City.  You have your basic residential and commercial and then as you grow you can get into the high density residential (skyscrapers) and high density commercial as well as office space.  Offices provide commerical output and don't generate noise like a typical commerical zone would.  Think an office versus a diner or gas station.  Day and night, rain and fog, as well as snow if you have the expansion are all weather effects.  The day and night were free additions to the game but the expansion for the nights adds other buildings as well.  You can adjust budgets per time of the day.  If you want, you can increase budget during the day hours and decrease the budget for the night hours since they have two independent sliders.  What I find interesting, is that school is also in session at night as well as a few other services that normally wouldn't run during that time.  Elementary at 2 am? Sure thing, get your♥♥♥♥♥to school.  There are mods out there and tons of add-on buildings that people have created using the asset and map editor.  There are so many mods that you could easily fill up a quarter of your harddrive if you went nuts about it.As I continue playing Cities: Ckylines, I find myself always coming back and wanting just 5 more minutes.  Sometimes I'll expand into a brand new district I have planned out and end up wanting to quit in 5 minutes but end up playing another 45.  This game can really take some time out of the day if you let it.  You can design a small town with sewage spilling into the river or expand enough to get water treatment plants and build dams.  If you don't want skyscrapers you can implement policies that limit how big the buildings can get, it is completely up to you.  For what it's worth, I haven't had this great of a time with a city simulation in quite some time.  Since the last Maxis Sim City now that I come to think of it.  With mods, you can easily fix some of the annoying problems like the traffic issue that I explained earlier in that they don't care if the highway is a parking lot, they would rather sit thre than take the new 6 lane bypass you built.  A few other things can get annoying too such as education and the industrial area not building to demographics.  It would have also been nice to deny education to certain schools for a more granular control process but there may also be a mod for that issue as well.A bunch of small issues that don't really get in the way of the big picture.  Build whatever you want, make it look awesome or turn it into North Korea.  Ultimately it is your choice and with a load of maps both official and custom, you won't get bored!

												This game is a lot better than Sim City... a LOT better. You can look at other reviews for why but here is why this game is awesome. Ive only played the game for 12 hours and I love it. Its not too much micro managing and not too sandbox. I fell in love when my city began to fall to ruin when my dumbass placed water towers in a heavily polluted industrial area. This quickly made everyone in the city ill and people began to die... rapidly. I went from making 20k+ a week to -10k a week. After I was in debt and lost over half of my city residents I realized what I had done. I fixed the problem and after destroying all of the abandoned houses and whatnot I was back on my feet. That moment when my cash flow was in the positives again was the most glorious moment in any city builder game I have experienced.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 4, 2015
												One of the best city builders ive played. With the backing of some of the best user created content i have seen this game offers a varied and unique experience on scales that are much more believable than previous city building games yet it is easy to pick up. The size of the buildable area really gives you the flexibility to build your towns and cities how you want them to be rather than being forced into a style based purely on space limitations.For anyone considering buying it or who already owns it, there are a few essential steam workshop items to have:-Road protractor (tells you the angle in degrees and length of any road being built from another road),-Extended Transport UI (makes it much easier to manage your transport routes once they have been placed),-ARIS remove stuck vehicles (requires ARIS skylines overwatch first and gives you the option to click on and then remove  any vehicle in game, which is essential!!),-All areas purchasable (enables the purchase of every tile on each map. You still start with 1 tile and have to purchase the tiles as normal but can build in a 5x5 area which makes the scales feel much more realistic) and finally-Prop Remover (autonomously monitors and removes certain ugly repeating signs such as the donut squirrels and identical illuminous billboards, this also makes my game run a tad smoother, especially at night)

The makers listen to what you have to say for the most part and it seems they are doing a fairly good job at keeping it intresting. I have yet to experance a CTD even using 26 mods. The more you play the more you figure out that its not as easy as it looks. I've clocked nearly 200 hours on the game and I've only had it little over a month. This game will suck you in and leave you dreaming of what to do next time in your city to make it a little bigger. UPDATE 3/16The new core content they added adds another level to playing, terain improvments and man made rivers, don't expect to get sleep now.......

Posted: December 3, 2016
												It has some flaws (like trains not working for s*** without a lot of gimmicks) but it's still the best city builder, period.The biggest con though, for me, is that it doesn't have an "organig" city growth and administration mechanic. Everything is more about "city designing" if you wish. You end up with cities that are always perfectly planned (the imperfections are only the ones you yourself put in). After you know how the mechanics work there will be little or even nothing to "suprise" you during game play. The game ends up being more about aestethics than it is about city management.I'd like so much for the cities to have a more realistic growth feeling.On the other hand, the pros are just way too long to list. It's good, it's beautiful, it's fun to design a city even if managing it is a bit lackluster. And the devs are pretty cool. The workshop and the modding community are phenomenal. Defo a worth buy.The DLCs, though... Not so much. They're ok, but mostly insanely overpriced for what you get.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												From loving games such as Sim City and Roller coaster Tycoon I have been looking for a good city management game for some time.  I can spend countless hours reworking roads to improve traffic flow and find laying water pips to be a peaceful experience. If that’s you, you might want to give this game a go. Unlike sim city, which it barrows heavily from there are no disasters. The biggest threat to your citizens will be fire. My few play throws the fire became a pain in how many burnt buildings I had to bulldoze. Though that was partly my fault I got rid of a street connecting the fire house. You could say the game was trying to bring my attention to this by burning the people of my city. City: Skylines is the definition of a city builder simulation game.  Its goal is to give you the tools to create a prosperous city the way you see fit. Through a wonderful mechanic called districts I could regulate an industry heavy district to provide farm goods. Personally I like my cities to be eco-friendly and concentrate on resident happiness instead of trying to make the most profitable city I can. From years of playing these types of games, the fun comes from living the fantasy of running your own city your way. City: Skylines seems to understand this. From their UI and overall look of the game people will compare it to Sim City 2013. Though I think as time goes on people will start to point out how this game sets it self apart. You can only see this through playing it.  It's a warm and welcoming feeling for people that want to dive into a city they can make into their own. This game also comes with a map and assets editor. From little I got to play with this feature I have to say its nice to create your own intersections to use in your maps. It keeps things uniform and saves you time from wasting cash and deleting unnecessary from roads that you have to replace, anyways. The developers have thought of steam workshop integrating from the get go. From seeing games of this type try to integrate other players into your game, like having a multiplayer function I much rather have this type of integration where players can add to each other's cities through making unique props, buildings and intersections. I would recommend this game to anyone that love city management games. It's one of the better ones.

												My city was large and in charge.  My city was energetic and up beat.  My city was the city that rivaled NYC until a flood, only comparable to the Chinese floods of 1931 was unleashed by the hand of god upon my luscious lands...my people didn't even see it coming.  They died angry and in a massive traffic jam.   10/10
